encodingDesc.p: The characters are identified by IDREF pointing to information in the following declarations. Lucretia Sextus Servius Tarquin Tullia Arnus Collatinus Brutus Horatius Valerius Valerius in Song stranger who played Valerius in postscript Song Lucretius Scevolo Clown/Pompey Oracle Priest Mirable/Lucretia's Maid Porsenna Soldier 1 Soldier 2 Maid 1 Maid 2 Servingman All/Omnes Secretary Lucretia's Letter

div1.head: THE RAPE OF LVCRECE, A true Roman Tragedy.
div1.p: To the Reader. It hath been no custome in me of all other men (courteous Reader) to commit my Playes to the Presse: the reason though some may attribute to my owne insufficiency, I had rather subscribe, in that, to their seveare censure, then by seeking to avoydthe imputation of weakenesse, to incurre greater suspition of honesty: for though some have used a double sale of their labours, first to the Stage, and after to the Presse: For my owne part, I here proclaime my selfe euer faithful in the first, and never guilty of the last: yet since some of my Playes have (unknowne to me, and without any of my direction) accidentally come into the Printers hands, and therefore so corrupt and mangled, copied onely by the eare) that I have beene as unable to know them, as ashamed to challenge them. This therefore I was the willinger to furnish out in his native habit: first being by consent, next because the rest have been so wronged, in being publisht in such savage and ragged ornaments: Accept it courteous Gentlemen, and proove as favourable Readers as we have found you gracious Auditors. Yours, T. H.

Dramatis Personae.
Servius King of Rome. Tarquin The proud. Tullia Wife of Tarquin Superbus, Aruns the Son of Tarquin. Sextus the Son of Tarquin. Brutus Iunior Colatinus Horatius Cocles. Mutius Scevola Lucretius Porsenna King of the Tuscans. Porsenna's Secretary. Pub. Valerius. The Priest of Apollo. 2. Centinels Lucretia ravisht by Sextus Myrabile Lucretius Maid. The Clowne.

body.head: SENATE.
body.stage: Enter Tarquin Superbus, Sextus Tarquinius, Tullia, Aruns, Lucretius, Valerius, Poplicola, and Senators before them.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.l: Withdraw! We must have private conference
With our dear husband

sp.speaker: Tar.
sp.l: What would thou wife?

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.l: Be what I am not, make thee greater far
Than thou canst aim to be

sp.speaker: Tar.
sp.l: Why, I am Tarquin.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.l: And I Tullia, what of that?
What Diapasons, more in Tarquins name
Than in a Subjects? or what is Tullia
More in the sound, than to become the name
Of a poor maid or waiting Gentlewoman?
I am a Princess both by birth and thoughts,
Yet all is but Tullia, there is no resonance
In a bare style: my title bears no breadth;
Nor hath it any state: O me, I am sick!

sp.speaker: Tar.
sp.l: Sick Lady?

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.l: Sick at heart.

sp.speaker: Tar.
sp.l: Why my sweet Tullia?

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.l: To be a queen I long, long, and am sick.
With ardency my hot appetite is a fire,
Till my swollen fever be delivered
Of that great title queen, my heart is all Royal,
Not to be circumscribed in servile bounds,
While there is a King that rules the Peers of Rome.
Tarquin makes legs, and Tullia curtsies low,
Bows at each nod, and must not near the state
Without obeisance, O! I hate this awe, my proud heart cannot brook it.

sp.speaker: Tar.
sp.l: Hear me wife.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.l: I am no wife of Tarquins if not King:
O had Iove made me man, I would have mounted
Above the base tribunals of the earth,
Up to the Clouds, for pompous sovereignty.
Thou art a man, O bare my royal mind,
Mount heaven, and see if Tullia lag behind,
There is no earth in me, I am all fire,
Were Tarquin so, then should we both aspire.

sp.speaker: Tar.
sp.l: O Tullia, though my body taste of dullness,
My soul is winged, to soar as high as thine,
But note what flags our wings, forty five years
The King thy father hath protected Rome.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.l: That makes for us: the people covet change,
Even the best things in time grow tedious.

sp.speaker: Tar.
sp.l: It would seem unnatural in thee, my Tullia,
The reverend King, thy father to depose:

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.l: A kingdoms quest, makes sons and fathers foes.

sp.speaker: Tar.
sp.l: And but by Servius fall we cannot climb,
The balm that must anoint us is his blood.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.l: Let us lave our brows then in that crimson flood,
We must be bold and dreadful: who aspires,
Mounts by the lives of Fathers, Sons, and Sires.

sp.speaker: Tar.
sp.l: And so must I, since for a kingdoms love,
Thou canst despise a Father for a Crown:
Tarquin shall mount, Servius be tumbled down,
For he usurps my state, and first deposed
My father in my swathed infancy,
For which he shall be countant: to this end
I have sounded all the Peers and Senators,
And though unknown to thee my Tullia,
They all embrace my faction; and so they
Love change of state, an new King to obey.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.l: Now is my Tarquin worthy Tullias grace.
Since in my arms, I thus a King embrace.

sp.speaker: Tar.
sp.l: The King should meet this day in Parliament.
With all the Senate and Estates of Rome,
His place will I assume, and there proclaim,
All our decrees in Royal Tarquins name.

body.stage: Florish. Enter Sextus, Aruns, Lucretius, Valerius, Collatine and Senators.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: May it please thee noble Tarquin to attend
The King this day in the high Capital?

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.l: Attend?

sp.speaker: Tar.
sp.l: We intend this day to see the Capital.
You knew our Father good Lucretius:

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I did my Lord.

sp.speaker: Tar.
sp.l: Was not I his Son?
The Queen my mother was of royal thoughts
And pure heart, as unblemished Innocence.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: What asks my Lord?

sp.speaker: Tar.
sp.l: Sons should succeed their fathers, but anon
You shall hear more, high time that we were gone.

body.stage: Florish. Exeunt Manet Collatine and Valerius.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: There is moral sure in this, Valerius.
Here is model, yea, and matter too to breed
Strange Meditations in the provident brains
Of our grave Fathers: some strange project lives
This day in Cradle that is but newly born.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
No doubt Colatine no doubt, here is a giddy and drunken
world, it Reels, it hath got the staggers, the commonwealth
is sick of an Ague, of which nothing can cure her but
some violent and sudden affrightment.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p:
The wife of Tarquin would be a Queen nay, of my
life she is with child till she be so.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
And longs to be brought to bed of a Kingdom, I divine,
We shall see some scuffling today in the Capital.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p:
If there be any difference among the Princes and Senate,
whose faction will Valerius follow?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
O Collatine, I am a true Citizen, and in this I will
best show myself to be one, to take part with the strongest.
If Servius overcome, I am Liegeman to Servius and if Tarquin
subdue, I am for vive Tarquinius.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p:
Valerius, no more, this talk does but keep us from
the sight of this solemnity: by this the Princes are entering the
Capital: come, we must attend.

body.stage: Tarquin, Tullia, Sextus, Aruns, Lucretius one way: Brutus meeting them the other way very humorously.

sp.speaker: Tar.
sp.l: This place is not for fools, this parliament
Assembles not the strains of Idiotism,
Only the grave and wisest of the Land:
Important are the affairs we have in hand.
Hence with that Mome.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Brutus forbear the presence.

sp.speaker: Brut.
sp.l: Forbear the presence! why pray?

sp.speaker: Sext.
sp.l: None are admitted to this grave concourse
But wise men: nay good Brutus.

sp.speaker: Brut.
sp.l: you will have an empty Parliament then.

sp.speaker: Aru.
sp.l: Here is no room for fools.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.p:
Then what makest thou here, or he, or he? O Iupiter!
if this command be kept strictly, we shall have empty Benches:
get you home you that are here, for here will be nothing
to do this day: a general concourse of wise men, it was never
seen since the first Chaos. Tarquin, if the general rule have
no exceptions thou wilt have an empty Consistory.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.p: Brutus you trouble us.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.p:
How powerful am I you Roman deities, that am able
to trouble her that troubles a whole Empire? fools exempted,
and women admitted! laugh Democritus, but have
you nothing to say to Mad-men?

sp.speaker: Tar.
sp.p: Madmen have here no place!

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.p:
Then out of doors with Tanquin, what is he that may
sit in a calm valley, and will choose to repose in a tempestuous
mountain, but a mad-man? that may live in tranquil pleasures,
and will seek out a kingdoms cares, but a madman?
who would seek innovation in a Common-wealth in public,
or be over-ruled by a cursed wife in private, but a fool or a madman?
give me thy hand Tarquin, shall we two be dismissed together
from the Capital?

sp.speaker: Tar.
sp.p: Restrain his folly.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.p: Drive the frantic hence.

sp.speaker: Aru.
sp.p: Nay Brutus.

sp.speaker: Sext.
sp.p: Good Brutus.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.p:
Nay soft, soft good blood of the Tarquins, let us have
a few cold words first, and I am gone in an instant, I claim
the privilege of the Nobility of Rome, and by that privilege
my seat in the Capitol. I am a Lord by birth, my place
is as free in the Capitol as Horatius, thine, or thine Lucretius,
thine Sextus, Aruns thine, or any here: I am a Lord and
you banish all the Lord fools from the presence, you will have
few to wait upon the King, but Gentlemen: nay, I am easily
persuaded then, hands off, since you will not have my company,
you shall have my room.
sp.l: My room indeed, for what I seem to be,
Brutus is not, but born great Rome to free.
The state is full of dropsy, and swollen big
With windy vapours, which my sword must pierce,
To purge the infected blood, bred by the pride
Of these infested bloods: nay now I go,
Behold I vanish since it is Tarquins mind,
One small fool goes, but great fools leaves behind.

sp.speaker: Lucre.
sp.l: It is pity one so generously derived,
Should be deprived his best inducements thus,
And want the true directions of the Soul.

sp.speaker: Tar.
sp.l: To leave these dilatory trifles, Lords
Now to the public business of the Land.
Lords take your several places.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Not great Tarquin, before the King assume his regal throne.
Whose coming we attend.

sp.speaker: Tulli.
sp.l: He has come already.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: The King?

sp.speaker: Tar.
sp.l: The King.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Servius?

sp.speaker: Tar.
sp.l: Tarquinus.

sp.speaker: Lucre.
sp.l: Servius is King.

sp.speaker: Tar.
sp.l: He was by power divine,
The Throne that long since he usurped is mine.
Here we enthrone ourselves, Cathedral state
Long since detained us, justly we resume,
Then let our friends and such as love us cry,
Live Tarquin and enjoy this Sovereignty.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Live Tarquin and enjoy this Sovereignty.

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.l: The King himself with such confederate Peers.
As stoutly embrace his faction, being informed
Of Tarquins Usurpation, armed comes,
Near to the entrance of the Capital.

sp.speaker: Tarq.
sp.l: No man give place, he that dares to arise
And do him reverence, we his love despise.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Traitor.

sp.speaker: Tar.
sp.l: Usurper.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Descend.

sp.speaker: Tullia.
sp.l: Sit still.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: In Servius name, Rome's great imperial Monarch,
I charge thee Tarquin disenthrone thyself,
And throw thee at our feet, prostrate for mercy.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Spoke like a King.

sp.speaker: Tar.
sp.l: In Tarquins name, now Rome's imperial Monarch,
We charge thee Servius make free resignation,
Of that arched-wreath thou hast usurped so long.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.l: Words worth an Empire.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Shall this be brooked my Sovereign:
Dismount the Traitor.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: Touch him he that dares.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Dares!

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.l: Dares.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Strumpet, no child of mine.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.l: Dotard, and not my father.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Kneel to thy King?

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.l: Submit thou to thy queen.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Insufferable treason with bright steel,
Lop down these interponents that withstand.
The passage to our throne.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: That Cocles dares.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: We with our steel guard Tarquin and his chair,

sp.speaker: Sce.
sp.l: A Servius.
Servius is slain.

sp.speaker: Aru.
sp.l: A Tarquin.

sp.speaker: Tar.
sp.l: Now are we king indeed, our awe is builded
Upon this Royal base, the slaughtered body
Of a dead King: we by his ruin rise
To a Monarchal Throne.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.l: We have our longing.
My fathers death gives me a second life
Much better than the first, my birth was servile,
But this new breath of reign is large and free,
Welcome my second life of Sovereignty.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I have a Daughter, but I hope of mettle,
Subject to better temperature, should my Lucrece
Be of this pride, these hands should sacrifice
Her blood unto the Gods that dwell below,
The abortive brat should not out-live my spleen,
But Lucrece is my Daughter, this my queen.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.l: Tear off the Crown, that yet impales the temples
Of our usurping Father: quickly Lords,
And in the face of his yet bleeding wounds,
Let us receive our honours.

sp.speaker: Tar.
sp.l: The same breath
Gives our state life, that was the Usurpers death.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.l: Here then by heavens hand we invest ourselves:
Music, whose loftiest tones grace Princes crowned,
Unto our novel Coronation sound.

body.stage: Florish. Enter Valerius with Horatius and Scevola.

sp.speaker: Tarq.
sp.l: Whom doth Valerius to our state present?

sp.speaker: Val
sp.l: Two valiant Romans, this Horatius Cocles,
This Gentleman called Mutius Scevola.
Who whilst King Servius wore the Diadem,
Upheld his sway and Princedom by their loves,
But he being fallen, since all the Peers of Rome
Applaud King Tarquin in his Sovereignty,
They with like suffrage greet your Coronation.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: This hand allied unto the Roman Crown,
Whom never fear dejected, or cast low,
Lays his victorious sword at Tarquins feet,
And prostrates with that sword allegiance.
King Servius life we loved, but he expired.
Great Tarquins life is in our hearts desired.

sp.speaker: Sce.
sp.l: Who whilst he rules with justice and integrity
Shall with our dreadless hands our hearts command,
Even with the best employments of our lives,
Since Fortune lifts thee, we submit to Fate,
Ourselves are vassals to the Roman state.

sp.speaker: Tarq.
sp.l: Your rooms were empty in our train of friends,
Which we rejoice to see so well supplied:
Receive our grace, live in our element favours,
In whose submission our young glory grows
To his ripe height: fall in our friendly train,
And strengthen with your loves our infant Reign.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: We live for Tarquin.

sp.speaker: Sce.
sp.p:
And to thee alone, whilst justice keeps thy sword
and thou thy Throne.

sp.speaker: Tar.
sp.l: Then are you ours, and now conduct us straight
In triumph through the populous streets of Rome.
To the Kings Palace our Majestic seat.
Your hearts though freely proffered, we entreat.

body.stage: Sennat. As they march, Tullia treads on her Father & staies.

sp.speaker: Tullia.
sp.l: What block is that we tread on?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: It is the body
Of your deceased Father Madam, Queen
Your shoe is crimsoned with his vital blood.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.l: No matter, let his mangled body lie,
And with his base confederates strew the streets,
That in disgrace of his usurped pride,
We over his trunk may in our Chariot ride:
For mounted like a Queen it would do me good
To wash my Coach-naves in my fathers blood.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Here is a good Child.

sp.speaker: Tar.
sp.l: Remove it we command, and bear his carcass to the funeral pile,
Where after this dejection, let it have
His solemn and due obsequies: fair Tullia,
Thy hate to him grows from thy love to us,
Thou showest thyself in this unnatural strife
An unkind Daughter, but a loving wife.
But on unto our Palace, this blessed day,
A Kings increase grows by a Kings decay.

sp.speaker: Brut.
sp.l: Murder the King! a high and Capital treason,
Those Giants that waged war against the Gods,
For which the overwhelmed Mountains hurled by Iove
To scatter them, and give them timeless graves
Was not more cruel than this butchery,
This slaughter made by Tarquin; but the Queen,
A woman, fie fie: did not this she-parricide
Add to her fathers wounds? and when his body
Lay all besmeared and stained in the blood royal,
Did not this Monster, this infernal hag,
Make her unwilling Charioteer drive on,
And with his shod wheels crush her Fathers bones?
Break his crazed scull, and dash his sparkled brains
Upon the pavements, whilst she held the reins?
The affrighted Sun at this abhorred object,
Put on a mask of blood, and yet she blushed not.
Iove art thou just; hast thou reward for piety?
And for offence no vengeance? or canst punish
Felons, and pardon Traitors? chastise Murderers,
And wink at Parricides? if thou be worthy,
As well we know thou art, to fill the Throne
Of all eternity, then with that hand
That flings the Trisulke thunder, let the pride
Of these our irreligious Monarchisers
Be Crowned in blood: this makes poor Brutus mad,
To see sin frolic, and the virtuous sad.

sp.speaker: Aru.
sp.p:
Soft, here is Brutus, let us acquaint him with the
news.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.p: Content: now Cousin Brutus.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.p:
Who, I your kinsman? though I be of the blood of
the Tarquins yet no cousin gentle Prince.

sp.speaker: Aru.
sp.p: And why so Brutus, Scorn you our alliance?

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.p:
No, I was cousin to the Tarquins, when they were
subjects, but dare claim no kindred as they are sovereigns:
Brutus is not so mad though he be merry, but he hath wit enough
to keep his head on his shoulders.

sp.speaker: Aru.
sp.p:
Why do you Lord thus lose your hours, and
neither profess war nor domestic profit? the first might
beget you love, the other riches.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.p:
Because I would live, have I not answered you, because
I would live? fools and mad men are no rubs in the
way of Usurpers, the firmament can brooke but one Sun,
and for my part I must not shine: I had rather live an obscure
black, then appear a fair white to be shot at, the end of all
is, I would live: had Servius been a shrub, the wind had not
shook him, or a mad-man, he not perished: I covet no
more wit nor employment than as much as will keep life and
soul together, I would but live.

sp.speaker: Aru.
sp.p:
You are satirical cousin Brutus, but to the purpose:
the king dreamt a strange and ominous dream last night, and
to be resolved of the event, my brother Sextus and I must to
the Oracle

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.p:
And because we would be well accompanied, we
have got leave of the king that you Brutus shall associate us,
for our purpose is to make a merry journey of it.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.p:
So you will carry, me along with you to be your fool
and make you merry.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.p: Not our fool, but --

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.p:
To make you merry: I shall, nay, I would make you
merry or tickle you till you laugh: the Oracle! I will go to be
resolved of some doubts private to myself: nay Princes, I
am so much endeared both to your loves and companies, that
you shall not have the power to be rid of me, what limits have
we for our journey?

sp.speaker: Sext.
sp.p: Five days, no more.

sp.speaker: Brut.
sp.p:
I shall fit me to your preparations, but one thing
more goes Collatine along?

sp.speaker: Sext.
sp.p:
Collatine is troubled with the common disease of all
new married men, he is sick of the wife, his excuse is forsooth
that Lucrece will not let him go, but you having neither
wife nor wit to hold you I hope will not disappoint us

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.p:
Had I both, yet should you, prevail with me above
either,

sp.speaker: Aru.
sp.p: We shall expect you.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.p:
Horatius Cocles, and Mutius Scevola are not engaged
in this expedition?

sp.speaker: Aru.
sp.l: No, they attend the King farewell.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Lucretius stays at home too and Valerius?

sp.speaker: Sext.
sp.l: The Palace cannot spare them.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: None but we three?

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: We three.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: We three, well five days hence.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: You have the time, farewell.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: The time I hope cannot be Circumscribed.
Within so short a limit, Rome and I
Are not so happy; what is the reason then,
Heaven spares his rod so long? Mercury tell me!
I have it, the fruit of pride is yet but green,
Not mellow, though it grows apace, it comes not
To his full height: Iove oft delays his vengeance,
That when it haps it may prove more terrible.
Despair not Brutus then, but let thy country
And thee take this last comfort after all,
Pride when thy fruit is ripe it must rot, and fall.
But to the Oracle.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I would I were no Romane.

sp.speaker: Sce.
sp.l: Cocles why?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I am discontented and dare not speak my thoughts.

sp.speaker: Sce.
sp.l: What, shall I speak them for you?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Mutius do.

sp.speaker: Scevo.
sp.l: Tarqin is proud.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Thou hast them.

sp.speaker: Scevo.
sp.l: Tyrannous.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: True.

sp.speaker: Sce.
sp.l: Insufferably lofty.

sp.speaker: Hor,
sp.l: Thou hast hit me.

sp.speaker: Scev.
sp.l: And shall I tell thee what I prophecy
Of his succeeding rule?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: No, I will do it for thee, Tarquins ability will in the weal,
Beget a weak unable impotence:
His strength, make Rome and our Dominions weak
His soaring high make us to flag our wings,
And fly close by the earth: his golden feathers
Are of such vastness, that they spread like sails,
And so becalm us that we have not air
Able to raise our plumes, to taste the pleasures of our own Elements.

sp.speaker: Scevo.
sp.p:
We are one heart, our thoughts and our desires
are suitable.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Since he was King he bears him like a God,
His wife like Pallas, or the wife of Iove.
Will not be spoke to without sacrifice,
And homage sole due to the Deities.

sp.speaker: Scevo.
sp.l: What haste with good Lucretius?

sp.speaker: Lucre.
sp.l: Haste but small speed,
I had an earnest suit unto the King,
About some business that concerns the weal
Of Rome and us, it will not be listened too,
He has took upon him such ambitious state,
That he abandons conference with his Peers,
Or if he chance to endure our tongues so much,
As but to hear their sonance, he despises
The intent of all our speeches, our advices,
And counsel: thinking his own judgment only
To be approved in matters military,
And in affairs domestic, we are but mutes,
And fellows of no parts, viols unstrung,
Our notes too harsh to strike in Princes ears.
Great Iove amend it.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Whither will von my Lord?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: No matter where it from the court, I will home to Collatine
And to my, daughter Lucrece: home breeds safety,
Dangers begot in Court, a life retired
Must please me now perforce: then noble Scevola,
And you my dear Horatius, farewell both,
Where industry is scorned let us welcome sloth.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Nay good Lucretius do not leave us thus,
See here comes Collatine, but where is Valerius?
How does he taste these times?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Not giddily like Brutus, passionately
Like old Lucretius with his tear swollen eyes,
Not laughingly like Mutius Scevola.
Nor bluntly like Horatius Cocles here.
He has usurped a stranger garb of humour,
Distinct from these in nature every way.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: How is he relished, can his eyes forbear?
In this strange state to shed a passionate tear.

sp.speaker: Sce.
sp.l: Can he forbear to laugh with Scevola,
At that which passionate weeping cannot mend?

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Nay can his thought shape ought but melancholy
To see these dangerous passages of state,
How is he tempered noble Collatine?

sp.speaker: Colla.
sp.l: Strangely, he is all song, he is ditty all,
Note that: Valerius hath given up the Court
And weaned himself from the Kings consistory
In which his sweet harmonious tongue grew harsh,
Whether it be that he is discontent,
Yet would not so appear before the King,
Or whether in applause of these new Edicts,
Which so distaste the people, or what cause
I know not, but now he is all musical.
Unto the Counsel chamber he goes singing,
And whilst the King his wilful Edicts makes,
In which nones tongue is powerful save the Kings,
He is in a corner relishing strange aires.
Conclusively he is from a toward hopeful Gentleman,
Trans-shaped to a mere Balladeer, none knowing
Whence should proceed this transmutation.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: See where he comes. Morrow Valerius.

sp.speaker: Lucre.
sp.l: Morrow my Lord.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: When Tarquin first in Court began,
And was approved King:
Some men for sudden joy gan weep,
But I for sorrow sing.

sp.speaker: Sce.
sp.l: Ha, ha, how long has my Valerius
Put on this strain of mirth, or what is the cause?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Let humour change and spare not,
Since Tarquin is proud, I care not,
His fair words so bewitch my delight,
That I doted on his sight.
Now he is changed cruel thoughts embracing
And my deserts disgracing.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Upon my life he is either mad or lovesick,
O can Valerius, but so late a States-man,
Of whom the public weal deserved so well,
Tune out his age in Songs and Cansoners.
Whose voice should thunder counsel in the ears
Of Tarquin and proud Tullia? think Valerius
What that proud woman Tullia is, it will put thee
Quite out of Tune.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Now what is love I will thee tell,
It is the fountain and the well,
Where pleasure and repentance dwell,
It is perhaps the sansing bell,
That rings all in to heaven or hell.
And this is love, and this is love, as I hear tell.
Now what is love I will you show,
A thing that creeps and cannot go:
A prize that passeth to and fro,
A thing for me, a thing for more,
And he that proves shall find it so,
And this is love, and this is love, sweet friend I trow.

sp.speaker: Lucre.
sp.l: Valerius. I shall quickly change thy cheer,
And make thy passionate eyes lament with mine,
think how that worthy Prince our kinsman King
Was butchered in the Marble Capital.
Shall Servius Tullius unregarded die
Alone of thee, whom all the Romane Ladies,
Even yet with tear swollen eyes, and sorrowful souls,
Compassionate as well he merited;
To these lamenting dames what canst thou sing?
whose grief through all the Romane Temples ring.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: Lament Ladies lament,
Lament the Roman land,
The King is from thee hent.
Was doughty on his hand,
We will gang into the Kirk,
His dead corps we will embrace,
And when we see him dead,
We aye will cry alas. Fa la.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: This music mads me, I all mirth despise.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: To hear him sing draws rivers from mine eyes.

sp.speaker: Sceuo.
sp.l: It pleaseth me for since the court is harsh,
And looks askance on soldiers, let us be merry,
Court Ladies, sing, drink, dance, and every man
Get him a mistress coach it in the Country,
And taste the sweets of it, what thinks Valerius
Of Sevolacs last counsel?

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: Why since we soldiers cannot prove,
And grief it is to us therefore,
Let every man get him a love,
To trim her well, and fight no more.
That we may taste of lovers bliss,
Be merry and blithe, embrace and kiss,
That Ladies may say some more of this,
That Ladies may say, some more of this.
Since Court and City both grow proud,
And safety you delight to hear,
We in the Country will us shroud,
Where lives to please both eye and ear:
The Nightingale sings Jug, Jug, Jug,
The little Lamb leaps after his dug,
And the pretty milkmaids they look so smug.
And the pretty milkmaids, etcetera.
Come Scevola shall we go and be idle?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I will in to weep.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: But I my gall to grate.

sp.speaker: Scevo.
sp.l: I will laugh at time, till it will change our Fate.

sp.speaker: Colla.
sp.l: Thou art not what thou seemest, Lord Scevola,
Thy heart mourns in thee, though thy visage smile,
And so does thy soul weep, Valerius,
Although thy habit sing, for these new humours
Are but put on for safety, and to arm them
Against the pride of Tarquin, from whose danger,
None great in love, in counsel; or opinion,
Can be kept safe: this makes me lose my hours
At home with Lucrece, and abandon court.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
Fortune I, embrace thee, that thou hast assisted me
in finding my master, the Gods of good Rome keep my
Lord and master out of all bad company.

sp.speaker: Colla.
sp.p: Sirrah the news with you.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
Would you have Court news, Camps news, City
news or Country news, or would you know what is the
news at home?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Let me know all the news.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
The news at Court is; that a small leg and a silk
stocking is in the fashion for your Lord: And the water that
God Mercury makes is in request with your Lady. The heaviness
of the kings wine makes many a light head and the emptiness
of his dishes many full bellies; eating and drinking was
never more in use: you shall find the baddest legs in boots,
and the worst faces in masks. They keep their old stomachs
still, the kings good Cook had the most wrong: for that
which was wont to be private only to him, is now usurped among
all the other officers: for now every man in his place,
to the prejudice of the master Cook, makes bold to lick his own fingers.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: The news in the camp.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
The greatest news in the camp is, that there is no
news at all, for being no camp at all, how can there be any
tidings from it?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Then for the city,

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p:
The Senators are rich, their wives fair, credit grows
cheap, and traffic dear, for you have many that are broke, the
poorest man that is, may take up what he will, so he will be
but bound (to a post till he pay the debt) There was one courtier
lay with twelve men's wives in the suburbs, and pressing
farther to make one more cuckold within the walls, and being
taken with the manner, had nothing to say for himself,
but this, he that made twelve made thirteen.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Now sir for the country.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
There is no news there but at the Ale-house, there is
the most receipt, and it is now strange my Lord, that so many
men love ale that know not what ale is.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Why, what is ale?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Why, ale is a kind of juice made of the precious grain
called Malt, and what is malt? Malt's M, A, L, T, and what is
M, A, L, T? M much, A ale, L little, T thirst, that is, much ale,
little thirst.

sp.speaker: Cola.
sp.p: Only the news at home and I have done.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
My Lady must needs speak with you about earnest
business, that concerns her nearly, and I was sent in all haste
to entreat your Lordship to come away.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: And couldst thou not have told me? Lucrece stay,
And I stand trifling here? follow, away.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
Aye marry sir, the way into her were a way worth following,
and that is the reason that so many Serving-man that
are familiar with their Mistresses, have lost the name of Servitors,
and are now called their masters Followers. Rest you
merry.

body.stage: Sound Musicke. Apollo's Priests with Tapers, after them, Aruns, Sextus and Brutus with their oblations, all kneeling before the Oracle.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.l: O thou Delphian god inspire
Thy Priests, and with celestial fire
Shot from thy beams crown our desire,
that we may follow,
In these thy true and hallowed measures,
The utmost of thy heavenly treasures,
According to the thoughts and pleasures
Of great Apollo.
Our hearts with inflammations burn,
Great Tarquin and his people mourn,
Till from thy Temple we return.
With some glad tiding.
Then tell us, Shall great Rome be blessed,
And royal Tarquin live in rest,
That gives his ennobled breast
To thy safe guiding?

sp.speaker: Oracle.
sp.l: Then Rome her ancient honours wins,
When she is purged from Tullia's sins.

sp.speaker: Brut.
sp.l: Gramercies Phoebus for these spells,
Phoebus alone, alone excels.

sp.speaker: Sext.
sp.l: Tullia perhaps sinned in our grandsires death,
And hath not yet by reconcilement made
Atone with Phoebus, at whose shrine we kneel:
Yet gentle Priest let us thus far prevail,
To know if Tarquins seed shall govern Rome,
And by succession claim the royal wreath?
Behold me younger of the Tarquins race:
This elder Aruns, both the sons of Tullia,
This Iunius Brutus, though a mad-man, yet
Of the high blood of the Tarquins.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.l: Sextus peace: Tell us, O thou that shinest so bright,
From whom the world receives his light,
Whose absence is perpetual night,
Whose praises ring:
Is it with heavens applause decreed,
When Tarquins soul from earth is freed,
That noble Sextus shall succeed
In Rome as King?

sp.speaker: Brut.
sp.l: Aye Oracle, hast thou lost thy tongue?

sp.speaker: Aru.
sp.l: Tempt him again fair Priest.

sp.speaker: Sext.
sp.l: If not as King, let Delphian Phoebus yet
Thus much resolve us, Who shall govern Rome,
Or of us three bear greatest pre-eminence?

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.l: Sextus I will, yet sacred Phoebus we entreat,
Which of these three shall be great
With largest power and state replete
By the heavens doom?
Phoebus thy thoughts no longer smother.

sp.speaker: Oracle.
sp.l: He that first shall kiss his mother.
Shall be powerful, and no other
Of you three in Rome.

sp.speaker: Sext.
sp.l: Shall kiss his mother!

sp.speaker: Brut.
sp.l: Mother Earth, to thee an humble kiss I tender.

sp.speaker: Aru.
sp.l: What means Brutus?

sp.speaker: Brut.
sp.p:
The blood of the slaughtered sacrifice made this floor
as slippery as the place where Tarquin treads, it is glassy and
as smooth as ice: I was proud to hear the Oracle so gracious
to the blood of the Tarquins and so I fell.

sp.speaker: Sext.
sp.l: Nothing but so, then to the Oracle.
I charge thee Aruns, Iunius Brutus thee,
To keep the sacred doom of the Oracle
From all our train, lest when the younger lad
Our brother now at home, sits dandled
Upon fair Tullias lap, this understanding
May kiss our beauteous mother, and succeed.

sp.speaker: Aru.
sp.l: Let the charge go round,
It shall go hard but I will prevent you Sextus.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.p:
I fear not the madman Brutus, and for Aruns let me
alone to buckle with him, I will be the first at my mothers lips
for a kingdom.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.p:
If the madman have not been before you Sextus, if Oracles
be Oracles, their phrases are mystical, they speak still in
clouds: had he meant a natural mother he would not have spoke
it by circumstance.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.p:
Tullia, if ever thy lips were pleasing to me, let it be
at my return from the Oracle.

sp.speaker: Aru.
sp.p:
If a kiss will make me a King, Tullia I will spring
to thee though through the blood of Sextus.

sp.speaker: Brut.
sp.p:
Earth I acknowledge no mother but thee, accept
me as thy Son, and I shall shine as bright in Rome as Apollo
himself in his temple at Delphos.

sp.speaker: Sext.
sp.l: Our Superstitions ended, sacred Priest,
Since we have had free answer from the Gods,
To whose fair altars we have done due right,
And hollowed them with presents acceptable,
let us now return, treading these holy measures,
With which we entered great Apollo's Temple.
Now Phoebus let thy sweet tuned organs sound,
Whose sphere like music must direct our feet
Upon the marble pavement: after this
We will gain a kingdom by a mothers kiss.

body.stage: A table and chaires prepared, Tarquin, Tullia, and Collatine, Scevola, Horatius, Lucretius, Valerius, Lords.

sp.speaker: Tarquin.
sp.l: Attend us with your persons, but your ears
Be deaf unto our counsels.

body.stage: The Lords fall off on either side and attend.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.l: Farther yet.

sp.speaker: Tarq.
sp.l: Now Tullia what must be concluded next?

sp.speaker: Tullia.
sp.l: The kingdom you have got by policy
You must maintain by pride.

sp.speaker: Tarquin.
sp.l: Good.

sp.speaker: Tullia.
sp.l: Those that were late of the King's faction
cut off for fear they prove rebellious.

sp.speaker: Tarq.
sp.l: Better.

sp.speaker: Tullia
sp.l: Since you gain nothing by the popular love,
Maintain by fear your Princedom.

sp.speaker: Tar.
sp.l: Excellent, thou art our Oracle and save from thee
We will admit no counsel, we obtained
Our state by cunning, it must be kept by strength.
And such as cannot love, we will teach to fear,
To encourage which upon our better judgment,
And to strike greater terror to the world,
I have forbid thy fathers funeral.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.l: No matter.

sp.speaker: Tar.
sp.l: All capital causes are by us discussed,
Traversed, and executed without counsel,
We challenge too by our prerogative,
The goods of such as strive against our state,
The freest Citizens without attaint,
Arraign, or judgment, we to exile doom,
The poorer are our drudges, rich our prey,
And such as dare not strive our rule obey.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.l: Kings are as Gods, and divine Sceptres bear,
The Gods command for mortal tribute, fear.
But Royal Lord, we that despise their love,
Must seek some means how to maintain this awe.

sp.speaker: Tar.
sp.l: By foreign leagues, and by our strength abroad.
Shall we that are degreed above our people,
Whom heaven hath made our vassals, reign with them?
No, Kings above the rest tribuned high,
Should with no meaner than with Kings ally:
For this we to Mamilius Tusculan
The Latin King have given in marriage
Our Royal daughter: Now his people is ours,
The neighbour Princes are subdued by arms:
And whom we could not conquer by constraint,
Them we have sought to win by courtesy,
Kings that are proud, yet would secure their own,
By love abroad, shall purchase fear at home.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.l: We are secure, and yet our greatest strength
Is in our children, how dare treason look
Us in the face having issue? barren Princes
Breed danger in their singularity,
Having none to succeed, their claim dies in them.

sp.speaker: Tar.
sp.l: Tullia is wise, and apprehensive, were our Princely sons
Sextus and Aruns back returned safe,
With an applausive answer of the Gods
From the Oracle, our state were able then
Being Gods ourselves, to scorn the hate of men.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: Where is Tullia?

sp.speaker: Aru.
sp.l: Where is our Mother?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Yonder Princes, at Council with the King.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.l: Our sons returned.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: Royal Mother.

sp.speaker: Aru.
sp.l: Renowned Queen.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: I love her best, therefore will Sextus do his duty first.

sp.speaker: Aru.
sp.l: Being eldest in my birth, I will not be youngest
In zeal to Tullia.

sp.speaker: Brut.
sp.l: To it Lads.

sp.speaker: Aruns.
sp.l: Mother a kiss.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: Though last in birth let me be first in love.
A kiss fair mother.

sp.speaker: Aru.
sp.l: Shall I lose my right?

sp.speaker: Sext.
sp.l: Aruns shall down, were Aruns twice my Brother,
If he presume fore me to kiss my mother.

sp.speaker: Aru.
sp.l: Aye Sextus, think this kiss to be a Crown, thus would we tug for it.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: Aruns thou must down.

sp.speaker: Tarq.
sp.l: Restrain them Lords.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Nay to it boys, O it is brave, they tug for shadows,
I the substance have.

sp.speaker: Aru.
sp.l: Through armed gates, and thousand swords I will break
To show my duty, let my valour speak.

body.stage: Breakes from the Lords and kisses her.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: O heavens! you have disolved me.

sp.speaker: Aru.
sp.l: Here I stand, what I have done to answer with this hand.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: O all ye Delphian Gods look down and see
How for these wrongs I will revenged be.

sp.speaker: Tar.
sp.l: Curb in the proud boys fury, let us know
From whence this discord riseth.

sp.speaker: Tullia.
sp.l: From our love, how happy are we in our issue now
When as our sons, even with their bloods contend
To exceed in duty, we accept your zeal.
This your superlative degree of kindness
So much prevails with us, that to the King
We engage our own dear love twixt his incensement
And your presumption, you are pardoned both.
And Sextus though you failed in your first proffer,
We do not yet esteem you least in love, ascend and touch our lips.

sp.speaker: Sext.
sp.l: Thank you, no.

sp.speaker: Tullia.
sp.l: Then to thy knee we will descend thus low.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: Nay now it shall not need: how great is my heart!

sp.speaker: Aru.
sp.l: In Tarquins Crown thou now hast lost thy part.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: No kissing now, Tarquin, great Queen adieu.
Aruns, on earth we have no foe but you.

sp.speaker: Tarq.
sp.l: What means this their unnatural enmity?

sp.speaker: Tullia.
sp.l: Hate, born from love.

sp.speaker: Tar.
sp.l: Resolve us then, how did the Gods accept
Our sacrifice, how are they pleased with us?
How long will they applaud our sovereignty?

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Shall I tell the King.

sp.speaker: Tar.
sp.l: Do Cousin, with the process of your journey.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.p:
I will. We went from hither, when we went from
hence, arrived thither when we landed there, made an end
of our prayers when we had done our Orisons, when thus
quoth Phoebus, Tarquin shall be happy whilst he is blessed,
govern while he reigns, wake when he sleeps not, sleep
when he wakes not, quaff when he drinks, feed when he
eats, gape when his mouth opens, live till he die, and die
when he can live no longer. So Phoebus commends him to
you.

sp.speaker: Tar.
sp.l: Mad Brutus still, Son Aruns, What say you?

sp.speaker: Aru.
sp.l: That the great Gods to whom the potent King
Of this large Empire sacrificed by us,
Applaud your reign, commend your sovereignty:
And by a general Synod grant to Tarquin,
Long days fair hopes Majesties government.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.p:
Adding withal, that to depose the late King which in
others, had been arch-treason, in Tarquin was honour: what in
Brutus had been usurpation, in Tarquin was lawful succession:
and for Tullia, though it be parricide for a child to kill her father,
in Tullia it was charity by death, to rid him of all his
calamities, Phoebus himself said she was a good child, and
shall not I say as he says, to tread upon her fathers skull,
sparkle his brains upon her Chariot wheel,
sp.l: And wear the sacred tincture of his blood
Upon her servile shoe? but more than this,
After his death deny him the due claim
Of all mortality, a funeral,
An earthen sepulchre, this, this, quoth the Oracle,
Save Tullia none would do.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.l: Brutus no more, least with the eyes of wrath and fury incensed
We look into thy honour: were not madness
And folly to thy words a privilege,
Even in thy last reproof of our proceedings
Thou hast pronounced thy death.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.p:
If Tullia will send Brutus abroad for news, and after
at his return not endure the telling of it: let Tullia either get
closer ears, or get for Brutus a stricter tongue.

sp.speaker: Tullia.
sp.l: How sir?

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: God be with ye.

sp.speaker: Tarq.
sp.l: Alas it is madness (pardon) not spleen,
Nor is it hate, but frenzy, we are pleased
To hear the Gods propitious to our prayers.
But whither has Sextus gone? resolve us Cocles.
We saw thee in his parting follow him.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: I heard him say, he would straight take his horse
And to the warlike Gabines enemies to Rome, and you.

sp.speaker: Tar.
sp.l: Save them we have no opposites.
Dares the proud boy confederate with our foes?
Attend us Lords, we must new battle wage,
And with bright arms confront the proud boys rage.

body.stage: Exeunt. Manet, Lucretius, Collatine, Horatius, Valerius, Scevola.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Had I as many souls as drops of blood
In these branched veins, as many lives as stars
Stuck in yond azure Rose, and were to die
More deaths than I have wasted weary minutes,
To grow to this, I would hazard all and more,
To purchase freedom to thus bondaged Rome.
I am vexed to see this virgin conqueress wear shackles in my sight.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
O would my tears would rid great Rome of these
prodigious fears.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.p:
What, weeping ripe Lucretius? possible? now Lords,
Lads, friends, fellows, young madcaps, gallants, and old courtly
ruffians, all subjects under one tyranny, and therefore should
be partners of one and the same unanimity. Shall we go single
ourselves by two and two, and go talk treason? then it is but
his yea, and my nay, if we be called to question: Or shall us go
use some violent bustling to break through this thorny servitude,
or shall we every man go sit like, O man in desperation,
and with Lucretius weep at Rome's misery: now am I for all
things anything or nothing, I can laugh with Scevola, weep
with this good old man, sing O hone hone with Valerius, fret
with Horatius Cocles, be mad like myself, or neutrize with
Collatine. Say what shall us do?

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: Fret.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Sing.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Weep.

sp.speaker: Scevo.
sp.p: Laugh.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.p:
Rather let us all be mad that Tarquin he still reigneth,
rome is still sad.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: You are madmen all that yield so much to passion.
You lay yourselves too open to your enemies,
That would be glad to pry into your deeds,
And catch advantage to ensnare our lives.
The kings fear, like a shadow, dogs you still,
Nor can you walk without it: I commend
Valerius most, and noble Scevola,
That what they cannot mend, seem not to mind,
By my consent let us all wear out our hours
In harmless sports: hawk, hunt, game, sing, drink, dance,
So shall we seem offenceless and live safe.
In dangers bloody jaws where being humorous,
Cloudy and curiously inquisitive
Into the Kings proceedings, there armed fear
May search into us, call our deeds to question,
And so prevent all future expectation:
Of wished amendment let us stay the time,
Till heaven have made them ripe for just revenge,
When opportunity is offered us,
And then strike home, till then do what you please:
No discontented thought my mind shall seize.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.p:
I am of Collatines mind now Valerius sing us a bawdy
song, and make us merry: nay it shall be so.

sp.speaker: Valer.
sp.p: Brutus shall pardon me.

sp.speaker: Scev.
sp.p:
The time that should have been seriously spent in
the State-house, I have learnt securely to spend in a wenching
house, and now I profess myself anything but a Statesman.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: The more thy vanity.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: The less thy honour.

sp.speaker: Valer.
sp.p: The more his safety, and the less his fear.

sp.l: She that denies me, I would have,
Who craves me, I despise.
Venus hath power to rule mine heart,
But not to please mine eyes.
Temptations offered, I still scorn.
Denied; I cling them still.
I will neither glut mine appetite,
Nor seek to starve my will.
Diana, double clothed, offends;
So Venus, naked quite.
The last begets a surfeit, and
The other no delight.
That crafty Girl shall please me best
That No, for Yea, can say,
And every wanton willing kiss
Can season with a Nay.

sp.speaker: Brut.
sp.p:
We have been mad Lords long, now let us be merry
Lords, Horatius maugre thy melancholy, and Lucreius in
spite of thy sorrow, I will have a song a subject for the ditty.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Great Tarquins pride, and Tullia's cruelty.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.p: Dangerous, no.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: The tyrannies of the Court, and vassalage of the City.

sp.speaker: Sce.
sp.p: Neither, shall I give the subject?

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.p: Do, and let it be of all the pretty wenches in Rome.

sp.speaker: Scev.
sp.p: It shall, shall it, shall it Valerius?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
Anything according to my poor acquaintance and
little conversance.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.p:
Nay you shall stay Horatius, Lucretius so shall you,
he removes himself from the love of Brutus, that shrinks
my side till we have had a song of all the pretty suburbans:
sit round, when Valerius?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Shall I woe the lovely Molly,
She is so fair, so fat so jolly,
But she has a trick of folly,
Therefore I will have none of Molly. No no no, no no, no.
I will have none of Molly, no no no.
O the cherry lips of Nelly,
They are red and soft as jelly,
But too well she loves her belly.
Therefore I will have none of Nelly. No, no, no, etcetera.
What say you to bonny Betty,
Have you seen a lass so pretty?
But her body is so sweaty,
Therefore I will have none of Betty. No, no, no, no, no,
When I dally with my Dolly,
She is full of melancholy,
O that wench is pestilent holly,
Therefore I will have none of Dolly, No, no, no, etcetera.
I could fancy lovely Nanny,
But she has the loves of many,
Yet herself she loves not any.
Therefore I will have none of Nanny, no, no, etcetera.
In a flax shop I spied Ratchell,
Where she her flax and tow did hatchel,
But her cheeks hang like a satchel,
Therefore I will have none of Ratchell, No, no, etcetera.
In a corner I met Biddy,
Her heels were light her head was giddy,
She fell down and somewhat did I,
Therefore I will have none of Biddy, No, no, etcetera.

sp.speaker: Brut.
sp.p:
The rest we will hear within, what offence is there in
this Lucretius? what hurt is in this Horatius? is it not better
to sing with our heads on, than to bleed with our heads off?
I never took Collatine for a Politician till now, come Valerius,
we will run over all the wenches of Rome, from the community of
lascivious Flora to the chastity of divine Lucrece, come good
Horatius.

body.stage: Exeunt. Enter Lucrece, Maide and Clowne.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: A Chair.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
A chair for my Lady, Mistress Mirable do you not
hear my Lady call.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Come near sir, be less officious
In duty, and use more attention,
Nay Gentlewoman we exempt not you
From our discourse, you must afford an ear
As well as he, to what we have to say.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: I still remain your handmaid.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Sirrah I have seen you oft familiar
With this my maid and waiting Gentlewoman,
As casting amorous glances, wanton looks,
And privy becks savouring incontinence,
I let you know you are not for my service
Unless you grow more civil.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
Indeed Madam for my own part I wish Mistress
Mirable well, as one fellow servant ought to wish to another,
but to say as that ever I flung any sheeps eyes in her face
how say you mistress Mirable did I ever offer it?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Nay Mistress, I have seen you answer him
With gracious looks, and some uncivil smiles,
Retorting eyes, and giving his demeanour
Such welcome as becomes not modesty,
Know hence-forth there shall no lascivious phrase,
Suspicious look, or shadow of incontinence,
Be entertained by any that attend, on Roman Lucrece.

sp.speaker: Maide.
sp.l: Madam, I!

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Excuse it not, for my premeditate thought
Speaks nothing out of rashness, nor vain hear say.
But what my own experience testifies
Against you both, let then this mild reproof,
Forewarn you of the like: my reputation
Which is held precious in the eyes of Rome,
Shall be no shelter to the least intent
Of looseness, leave all familiarity,
sp.p:
And quite renounce acquaintance, or I here, discharge you
both my service.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
For my own part Madam, as I am a true Roman
by nature, though no Roman by my nose, I never spent the
least lip labour on mistress Mirable, never so much as glanced,
never used any winking or pinking, never nodded at her, no
not so much as when I was asleep, never asked her the question
so much as what is her name: if you bring any man,
woman, or child, that can say so much behind my back, as
for he did but kiss her, for I did but kiss her and so let her go:
let my Lord Collatine instead of plucking my coat, pluck
my skin over my ears and turn me away naked, that wheresoever
I shall come I may be held a raw Serving man hereafter.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Sirrah, you know our mind.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
If ever I knew what belongs to these cases, or yet know
what they mean, if ever I used any plain dealing, or were ever
worth such a jewel, would I might die like a beggar: if
ever I were so far read in my Grammar, as to know what an Interjection
is, or a conjunction Copulative, would I might
never have good of my qui quoe quod: why, do you think Madam
I have no more care of myself being but a stripling,
then to go to it at these years? flesh and blood cannot endure
it, I shall even spoil one of the best faces in Rome
with crying at your unkindness.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
I have done, see if you can spy your Lord returning from
the Court, and give me notice what strangers he brings home
with him.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Yes I will go, but see kind man he saves me a labour.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p:
Come Valerius let us hear in our way to the house of
Collatine, that you went late hammering of concerning
the Taverns in Rome.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Only this Horatius.

sp.l: The Gentry to the Kings head,
The Nobles to the Crown.
The Knights unto the golden Fleece,
And to the plough the Clown.
The Church-man to the Mitre.
The Shepherd to the Star.
The Gardiner, hies him to Rose,
To the Drum the man of war;
To the Feathers Ladies you; the Globe
The Sea-man doth not scorn
The Usurer to the Devil, and
The Townsman to the Horn.
The Huntsman to the white Hart,
To the Ship the Merchant goes,
But you that do the Muses love
The Swan, called River Poe.
The Bankrupt to the worlds end,
The Fool to the Fortune hie.
Unto the Mouth, the Oyster wife,
The Fiddler to the Pie,
The Punk unto the Cockatrice.
The Drunkard to the Vine,
The Beggar to the Bush, then meet
And with Duke Humphrey Dine.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p:
Fair Lucrece, I have brought these Lords from Court
to feast with thee, sirrah prepare us dinner.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
My Lord is welcome, so are all his friends, the news
at Court Lords.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p:
Madam strange news: Prince Sextus by the enemies
of Rome.
sp.l: Was nobly used, and made their General,
Twice hath he met his father in the field,
And foiled him by the Warlike Gabines aid:
But how hath he rewarded that brave Nation,
That in his great disgrace supported him?
I will tell you Madam he since the last battle
Sent to his Father a close messenger
To be received to grace, withal demanding
What he should do with those his enemies?
Great Tarquin from his son receives this news,
Being walking in his Garden: when the messenger
Importuned him for answer, the proud King
Lops with his wand the heads of Poppies off,
And says no more; with this uncertain answer
The messenger to Sextus back returns,
Who questions of his Fathers words, looks, gesture?
He tells him that the haughty speechless King
Straight apprehend, cuts off the great men's heads,
And having left the Gabines without govern,
Flies to his father, and this day is welcomed
For this his traitorous service by the King,
With all due solemn honours to the Court.

sp.speaker: Scevo.
sp.p:
Courtesy strangely requited, this none but the son
of Tarquin would have enterprised.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
I like it, I applaud it, this will come to somewhat in
the end, when heaven has cast up his account, some of them
will be called to a hard reckoning. For my part, I dreamt last
night I went a fishing.

sp.l: Though the weather jangles
With our hooks, and our angles,
Our nets be shaken, and no fish taken:
Though fresh Cod and Whiting,
Are not this day biting,
Gurnet, nor Conger, to satisfy hunger,
Yet look to our draught.
Hale the main bowling,
The seas have left their rolling,
The waves their huffing, the winds their puffing,
Up to the Top-mast Boy,
And bring us news of joy,
Here is no demurring, no fish is stirring.
Yet some thing we have caught.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Leave all to heaven.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
My Lords, the best plum porridge in all Rome cools
for your honours, dinner is piping hot upon the table: and if
you make not the more haste, you are like to have but cold
cheer: the Cook hath done his part, and there is not a dish
on the dresser but he has made it smoke for you, if you have
good stomachs, and come not in while the meat is hot,
you will make hunger and cold meet together.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: My man is a Rhetorician I can tell you,
And his conceit is fluent: Enter Lords,
You must be Lucrece guests, and she is scant
In nothing, for such Princes must not want.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
My Lord Valerius, I have even a suit to your honour,
I have not the power to part from you, without a relish, a note,
a tone, we must get an Air betwixt us,

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Thy meaning.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Nothing but this,
Iohn for the King has been in many ballads,
Iohn for the King down dino,
Iohn for King, has eaten many salads,
Iohn for the King sings hey ho.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Thou wouldst have a song, wouldst thou not?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
And be everlastingly bound to your honour, I am
now forsaking the world and the Devil, and somewhat leaning
towards the flesh, if you could but teach me how to
choose a wench fit for my stature and complexion, I should
rest yours in all good offices.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I will do that for thee, what is thy name?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: My name sir is Pompie.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Well then attend.

sp.l: Pompie I will show thee, the way to know
A dainty dapper wench.
First see her all bare, let her skin be rare
And be touched with no part of the French:
Let her looks be clear, and her brows severe,
Her eyebrows thin and fine:
But if she be a punk, and love to be drunk,
Then keep her still from the wine.
Let her stature be mean, and her body clean,
Thou canst not choose but like her:
But see she have good clothes, with a fair Roman nose,
For that is the sign of a striker.
Let her legs be small, but not used to sprawl,
Her tongue not too loud nor cocket.
Let her arms be strong, and her fingers long,
But not used to dive in pocket.
Let her body be long, and her back be strong,
With a soft lip that entangles,
With an ivory breast, and her hair well dressed,
Without gold lace or spangles.
Let her foot be small, clean legged withal,
Her apparel not too gaudy:
And one that hath not been, in any house of sin,
Nor place that hath been bawdy.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
But Gods me, am I trifling here with you, and dinner
cools at the tables and I am called to my attendance, O my
sweet Lord Valerius!

body.stage: Enter Tarquin, Porsenna, Tullia, Sextus, Aruns.

sp.speaker: Tarq
sp.l: Next King Porsenna, whom we tender dearly,
Welcome young Sextus, thou hast to our yoke,
Suppressed the neck of a proud nation
The warlike Gabins, enemies to Rome.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: It was my duty Royal Emperor,
The duty of a Subject and a son.
We at our mothers intercession likewise,
Are now atoned with Aruns whom we here receive into our bosom.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.l: This is done like a kind brother and a natural son.

sp.speaker: Aru.
sp.p:
We interchange a royal heart with Sextus, and
graft us in your love.

sp.speaker: Tarq.
sp.p:
Now King Porsenna, welcome once more, to Tarquin
and to Rome.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: We are proud of your alliance, Rome is ours,
And we are Rome's, this our religious league
Shall be carved firm in Characters of brass,
And live for ever to succeeding times.

sp.speaker: Tar.
sp.l: It shall Porsenna, now this league is established.
We will proceed in our determined wars,
To bring the neighbour Nations under us,
Our purpose is to make young Sextus General
Of all our army, who hath proved his fortunes
And found them full of favour: we will begin
With strong Ardea, have you given in charge
To assemble all our Captains, and take muster of our strong army?

sp.speaker: Aru.
sp.l: That business is dispatched.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.p:
We have likewise sent for all our best commanders to
take charge according to their merit: Lord Valerius,
sp.l: Lord Brutus, Cocles, Mutius Scevola,
And Collatine to make due preparation for such a gallant siege.

sp.speaker: Tarq.
sp.l: This day you shall set forward, Sextus go,
And let us see your army march along.
Before this King and us, that we may view
The puissance of our host prepared already,
To lay high reared Ardea waste and low.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: I shall my Liege.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.l: Aruns associate him.

sp.speaker: Aru.
sp.l: A rival with my brother in his honours.

sp.speaker: Tar.
sp.l: Porsenna shall behold the strength of Rome,
And body of the Camp, under the charge
Of two brave Princes, to lay hostile siege
Against the strongest City that withstands
The all-commanding Tarquin,

sp.speaker: Pors.
sp.l: It is an object to please Porsennaes eye.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: The host is now upon their March.
You from this place may see
The pride of all the Roman Chivalry.

body.stage: Sextus, Aruns, Brutus, Collatine, Valerius, Scevola, Cocles, with souldiers, drum and colours, march over the stage, and congee to the King and Queene.

sp.speaker: Pors.
sp.l: This sight is more pleasing to Porsennaes eye,
Than all our rich Attalia pompous feasts,
Or sumptuous revels: we are born a Soldier,
And in our nonage sucked the milk of war.
Should any strange fate lower upon this army
Or that the merciless gulf of confusion
Should swallow them, we at our proper charge,
And from our native confines vow supply
Of men and arms to make these numbers full.

sp.speaker: Tarq.
sp.l: You are our Royal brother, and in you,
Tarquin is powerful and maintains his awe.

sp.speaker: Tullia.
sp.l: The like Porsenna may command of Rome,

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: But we have (in your fresh varieties)
Feasted too much, and kept ourself too long
From our own seat, our prosperous return
Hath been expected by our Lords and Peers.

sp.speaker: Tarq.
sp.l: We have best leisure for your entertainment,
Which now shall want no due solemnity.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: It hath been beyond both expectation
And merit, but in sight of heaven I swear,
If ever royal Tarquin shall demand it is ready stored for you
Even in our Kingly breast.

sp.speaker: Tar.
sp.l: The like we vow to King Porsenna, we will yet a little
Enlarge your royal welcome with Rareties,
Such as Rome yields: that done, before we part,
Of too remote Dominions make one heart.
Set forward then, our sons wage war abroad,
To make us peace at home: we are of ourself
Without supportance, we all fate defy,
Aidless, and of ourself we stand thus hie.

body.stage: Exeunt. Two souldiers meet as in the watch.

sp.l: Stand, who goes there?
A friend.

sp.p:
Stir not, for if thou dost I will broach thee straight
upon this pike. The word?

sp.speaker: 2. Sol.
sp.l: Porsenna.
Pass, stay, who walks the round tonight,
The general, or any of his Captains?

sp.speaker: 2. Sol.
sp.l: Horatius hath the charge, the other Chieftains,
Rest in the Generals tent, there is no commander
Of any note, but revel with the Prince:
And I amongst the rest am charged to attend
Upon their Rouse.

sp.speaker: 1. Sol.
sp.l: Pass freely, I this night must stand,
Twixt them and danger, the time of night?

sp.speaker: 2. Sol.
sp.l: The clock last told eleven.

sp.speaker: 1. Sol.
sp.p:
The powers celestial that have took Rome in
charge, protect it still.
sp.l: Again good night, thus must poor Soldiers do,
Whilst their commanders are with dainties fed,
And sleep on Down, the earth must be our bed.

body.stage: Exit. A banquet prepared. Enter Sextus, Aruns, Brutus, Valerius, Horatius, Scevola, Collatine.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: Sit round, the enemy is pounded fast
In their own folds, the walls made to oppugn,
Hostile incursions become a prison,
To keep them fast for execution;
There is no eruption to be feared.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.p:
What shall us do? Come a health to the generals
health; and Valerius that sits the most civilly shall begin it, I
cannot talk till my blood be mingled with this blood of
grapes: Fill for Valerius, thou shouldst drink well, for thou
hast been in the German wars, if thou lovest me drink up se
freeza.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.p:
Nay since Brutus has spoke the word, the first health
shall be imposed on you Valerius, and if ever you have been
Germanised, let it be after the Dutch fashion

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.p: The general may command.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.p: He may, why else is he called the commander?

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.p: We will entreat Valerius.

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.p:
Since you will needs enforce a high German health,
look well to your heads, for I come upon you with this
Dutch Tassaker: if you were of a more noble science than you
are, it will go near to break your heads round.

sp.l: O Mork giff men ein man,
Skerry merry vip,

l.foreign: O morke giff men ein man

sp.l: O morke giff men ein man,
that tik die ten long o drievan ean,

l.foreign: Skerry merry vip, and skerry merry vap

sp.l: and skerry merry runke ede sunk,

l.foreign: Ede hoore was a hai dedle downe

sp.l: Dedle drunke a:
Skerry merry runke ede bunk, ede hoore was drunk a.
O daughter yeis in alto kleene,
Skerry merry vip,
O daughter yeis ein alto kleene,
Skerry merry vap,
O daughter yeis in alto kleene,

l.foreign: Ye molten slop, ein yert a leene
Skerry merry vip, and skerry merry vap

sp.l: And skerry merry runk ede bunk.

l.foreign: Ede hoore was a hey dedte downe

sp.l: Dedle drunke a:
Skerry merry, runke ede bunk ede hoore was drunke a.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.p:
Gramercies Valerius, came this hie-German health
as double as his double ruff, I would pledge it.

sp.speaker: Brut.
sp.p:
Where it Lubecks or double double beer, their own
natural liquor I would pledge it were it as deep as his ruff: let the
health go round about the board, as his band goes round about
his neck. I am no more afraid of this dutch fashion,
than I should be of the heathenish invention.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p:
I must entreat you spare me for my brain brooks not
the fumes of wine, their vaporous strength offends me much.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p:
I would have none spare me for I will spare none, Collatine
will pledge no health unless it be to his Lucrece.

sp.speaker: Sext.
sp.l: What is Lucrece but a woman, and what are women
But tortures and disturbance unto men?
If they be foul they are odious, and if fair,
They are like rich vessels full of poisonous drugs,
Or like black serpents armed with golden scales:
For my own part they shall not trouble me.

sp.speaker: Brutus.
sp.p:
Sextus sit fast for I proclaim myself a woman's
champion and shall unhorse thee else.

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.p:
For my own part I am a married man, and I will speak
to my wife to thank thee Brutus.

sp.speaker: Aru.
sp.p:
I have a wife too, and I think the most virtuous
Lady in the world.

sp.speaker: Sce.
sp.p:
I cannot say but that I have a good wife too, and I
love her: but if she were in heaven, beshrew me if I would
wish her so much hurt as to desire her company upon earth
again, yet upon my honour, though she be not very fair,
she is exceeding honest.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.p:
Nay the less beauty, the less temptation to despoil
her honesty.

sp.speaker: Sce.
sp.p:
I should be angry with him that should make question
of her honour.

sp.speaker: Brut.
sp.p:
And I angry with thee if thou shouldst not maintain
her honour.

sp.speaker: Aru.
sp.p:
if you compare the vertues of your wives, let me
step in for mine.

sp.speaker: Colla.
sp.p: I should wrong my Lucrece not to stand for her.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.p:
Ha, ha, all captains, and stand upon the honesty of
your wives; is it possible think you that women of young spirit
and Full age, of fluent wit, that can both sing and dance,
sp.l: Read, write, such as feed well and taste choice cates,
That straight dissolve to purity of blood,
That keep the veins full, and inflame the appetite
Making the spirit able, strong, and prone,
Can such as these their husbands being away
Employed in foreign sieges or else where,
Deny such as importune them at home?
Tell me that flax will not be touched with fire,
Nor they be won to what they most desire?

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Shall I end this controversy in a word?

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: Do good Brutus.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: I hold some holy, but some apt to sin,
Some tractable, but some that none can win,
Such as are virtuous, Gold nor wealth can move,
Some vicious of themselves are prone to love.
Some grapes are sweet and in the Garden grow.
Others unpruned turn wild neglected so.
The purest ore contains both Gold and dross,
The one all gain, the other naught but loss.
The one disgrace, reproach, and scandal taints,
The other angels and sweet featured Saints.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Such is my virtuous, Lucrece.

sp.speaker: Aru.
sp.l: Yet she for virtue not comparable to the wife of Aruns

sp.speaker: Sce.
sp.p:
And why may not mine be ranked with the most
virtuous?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p:
I would put in for a lot, but a thousand to one I shall
draw but a blank.

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.p:
I should not show I loved my wife, not to take her
part in her absence: I hold her inferior to none.

sp.speaker: Aru.
sp.p: Save mine.

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.p: No not to her.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.p:
O this were a brave controversy for a jury of women
to arbitrate.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: I will hazard all my fortunes on the vertues
Of divine Lucrece, shall we try them thus?
It is now dead of night, let us mount our steeds,
Within this two hours we may reach to Rome,
And to our houses all come unprepared,
And unexpected by our hie praised wives,
She of them all that we find best employed,
Devoted, and most housewife exercised,
Let her be held most virtuous, and her husband
Win by the wager a rich horse and armour.

sp.speaker: Aru.
sp.l: A hand on that.

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.l: Here is a helping hand to that Bargain.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: But shall we to horse without circumstance?

sp.speaker: Sce.
sp.l: Scevola will mounted with the first.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.p:
Then mount, Chevall Brutus this night take you the
charge of the army, I will see the trial of this wager, it would do
me good to see some of them find their wives in the arms of
their Lovers, they are so confident in their vertues: Brutus
we will interchange, good night, be thou but as provident over
the Army as we (if our horses fail not) expeditious in our
journey: to horse, to horse.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Farewell good Brutus.

body.stage: Exeunt. Enter Lucrece and her two maids.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: But one hour more and you shall all to rest:
Now that your Lord is absent from this house,
And that the masters eye is from his charge,
We must be careful, and with providence
Guide his domestic business, we have now
Given over all feasting and left revelling,
Which ill becomes the house whose Lord is absent.
We banish all excess till his return,
In fear of whom my soul doth daily mourn.
Madam, so please you, to repose yourself
Within your Chamber, leave us to our tasks,
We will not loiter, though you take your rest.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Not so, you shall not overwatch yourselves
Longer than I wake with you, for it fits
Good housewives, when their husbands are from home,
To eye their servants labours, and in care,
And the true manage of his household state,
Earliest to rise, and to be up most late.
Since all his business he commits to me,
I will be his faithful steward till the Camp
Dissolve and he return, thus wives should do,
In absence of their Lords be husbands too.

sp.p:
Madam, the Lord Turnus his man was thrice for you
here, to have entreated you home to supper, he says his Lord
takes it unkindly he could not have your company,

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: To please a loving husband, I will offend
The love and patience of my dearest friend,
Methinks his purpose was unreasonable
To draw me in my husbands absence forth,
To feast and banquet, it would have ill become me,
To have left the charge of such a spacious house without both
Lord and Mistress:
I am opinioned thus: Wives should not stray
Out of their doors their husbands being away:
Lord Turnus excuse me.
Pray Madam, set me right into my work.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Being abroad, I may forget the charge
Imposed me by my Lord, or be compelled
To stay out late, which were my husband here,
Might be, without distaste, but he from hence,
With late abroad, there can no excuse dispense.
Here, take your work again, a while proceed,
And then to bed, for whilst you sow I will read.

body.stage: Enter Sextus, Aruns, Valerius, Collatine, Horatius, Scevola.

sp.speaker: Aru.
sp.p:
I would have hazarded all my hopes, my wife had
not been so late a revelling.

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.p: Nor mine at this time of night a-gambolling.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p:
They wear so much Cork under their heels they
cannot choose but love to caper.

sp.speaker: Sce.
sp.p:
Nothing does me good, but that if my wife were
watching, all theirs were wantoning, and if I have lost, none
can brag of their winnings.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.p:
Now Collatine to yours, either Lucrece must be better
employed than the rest, or you content to have her vertues
ranked with the rest.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I am pleased.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p:
Soft, soft let us steal upon her as upon the rest, least
having some watch-word at our arrival, we may give her notice
to be better prepared: nay by your leave Collatine, we will
limit you no advantage.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: See Lords, thus Lucrece revels with her maids,
sp.p:
In stead of riot, quaffing, and the practise of high lavoltas to
the ravishing sound of chambering music, she like a good
housewife is teaching of her servants sundry chores, Lucrece?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: My Lord and husband welcome, ten times welcome.
Is it to see your Lucrece you thus late
Have with your persons hazard left the Camp,
And trusted to the danger of a night so dark, and full of horror.

sp.speaker: Aru.
sp.l: Lords all is lost.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p:
By Iove I will buy my wife a wheel, and make her spin
for this trike.

sp.speaker: Sce.
sp.p:
If I make not mine learn to live by the prick of her
needle for this I am no Roman.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Sweet wife salute these Lords, thy continence
Hath won thy husband a Barbary horse and a rich coat of arms

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: O pardon me, the joy to see my Lord,
Took from me all respect of their degrees,
The richest entertainment lives with us,
According to the hour and the provision
Of a poor wife in the absence of her husband,
We prostate to you, howsoever mean,
We thus excuse it, Lord Collatines away.
We neither feast, dance, quaff, riot, nor play,

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.p:
If one woman among so many bad, may be found
good, If a white wench may prove a black swan, it is Lucrece,
her beauty hath relation to her virtue, and her virtue correspondent
to her beauty, and in both she is matchless.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Lords will you yield the wager?

sp.speaker: Aru.
sp.p:
Stay, the wager was as well which of our Wives
was fairest too, it stretched as well to their beauty as to their
continence, who shall judge that?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p:
That can none of us, because we are all parties, let
Prince Sextus determine it who hath been with us, and been an
eye witness of their beauties.

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.l: Agreed.

sp.speaker: Sce.
sp.l: I am pleased with the censure of Prince Sextus.

sp.speaker: Aru.
sp.l: So are we all.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: I commit my Lucrece holy to the dispose of Sextus.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: And Sextus commits him holy to the dispose of Lucrece
I love the Lady and her grace desire,
Nor can my love wrong what my thoughts admire.
Aruns, no question but your wife is chaste,
And thrifty, but this Lady knows no waste.
Valerius, yours is modest, something fair,
Her grace and beauty are without compare,
Thine Mutius well disposed, and of good feature,
But the world yields not so divine a creature.
Horatius, thine a smug lass and graced well,
But amongst all, fair Lucrece doth excel.
Then our impartial heart and judging eyes,
This verdict gives, fair Lucrece wins the prize.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Then Lords you are indebted to me a horse and armour.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: We yield it.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
Will you taste such welcome Lords, as a poor unprovided
house can yield?

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.p:
Gramercy Lucrece, no, we must this night sleep by
Ardea walls.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: But my Lords, I hope my Collatine will not so leave his Lucrece

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.p:
He must, we have but idled from the Camp, to try a
merry wager about their wives, and this the hazard of the kings
displeasure, should any man be missing from his charge: the
powers that govern Rome make divine Lucrece for ever
happy, good night.

sp.speaker: Sce.
sp.p:
But Valerius, what thinkest thou of the country girls
from whence we came, compared with our city wives whom
we this night have tried.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Scevola thou shall hear.

sp.l: O yes, room for the Crier,
Who never yet was found a liar.
O ye fine smug country Lasses,
That would for Brooks change crystal Glasses,
And be trans-shaped from foot to crown,
And Straw-beds change for beds of Down;
Your Partlets turn into Rebatoes,
And stead of Carrots eat Potatoes;
Your Fronlets lay by, and your Rails,
And fringe with gold your daggled Tails:
Now your Hawk-noses shall have Hoods
And Billements with golden Studs:
Straw-hats shall be no more Bongraces
From the bright Sun to hide your faces,
For hempen smocks to help the Itch,
Have linen, sewed with silver stitch;
And wheresoever they chance to stride,
One bare before to be their guide.
O yes, room for the Crier,
who never yet was found a liar.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Will not my husband repose this night with me?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p:
Lucrece shall pardon him, we have took our leaves of
Our wives, nor shall Collatine be before us though our Ladies
in other things come behind you.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p:
I must be swayed: the joys and the delights of many
thousand nights meet all in one to make my Lucrece happy.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I am bound to your strict will, to each good-night.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: To horse, to horse Lucrece we cannot rest,
Till our hot lust embosom in thy breast.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: With no unkindness we should our Lords upbraid,
Husbands and Kings must always be obeyed.
Nothing save the high business of the state,
And the charge given him at Ardeas siege,
Could have made Collatine so much digress,
From the affection that he bears his wife.
But subjects must excuse when Kings claim power.
But leaving this before the charm of sleep,
Cease with his downy wings upon my eyes,
I must go take account among my servants
Of their days task, we must not cherish sloth,
No covetous thought makes me thus provident,
But to shun, Idleness which wise men say,
Begets rank lust, and virtue beats away.

body.stage: Exit. Enter Sextus, Aruns, Horatius, Brutus, Scevola, Valerius.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p:
Return to Rome now we are in the midway to the
Camp?

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: My Lords, it is business that concerns my life.
Tomorrow if we live we will visit thee.

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.l: Will Sextus enjoin me to accompany him?

sp.speaker: Sce.
sp.l: Or me?

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: Nor you, nor any, it is important business
And serious occurrences that call me,
Perhaps Lords I will commend you to your wives.
Collatine shall I do you any service to your Lucrece?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: only commend me.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: What, no private token to purchase our kind welcome?

sp.speaker: Col,
