sp.p:
Would Royal Sextus would but honour me to bear
her a slight token.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: This Ring,

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: As I am Royal I will see it delivered.
This Ring to Lucrece shall my love convey,
And in this gift thou dost thy bed betray.
Tomorrow we shall meet, this night sweet fate,
May I prove welcome though a guest ingrate.

sp.speaker: Aru.
sp.p:
He is for the City, we for the Camp, the night makes
the way tedious and melancholy, prithee a merry song to
beguile it.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: There was a young man and a maid fell in love,
Terry derry ding, terry tery ding, tery tery dino.
To get her good will he often did,
Terry derry ding, terry derry ding langtido dille,
There is many will say, and most will allow, tery derry etcetera.
There is nothing so good as a terry derry derry, etcetera.
I would wish all maids before they be sick, terry derry, etcetera.
To inquire for a young man that has a good terry derry, etcetera.

sp.speaker: Sce.
sp.p:
Nay, my Lord, I heard them all have a conceit of
an Englishman, a strange people, in the western Islands,
one that for his variety in habit, humour and gesture, put
down all other nations whatsoever, a little of that if you
love me.

sp.speaker: Valle.
sp.p: Well Scevola, you shall.

sp.l: The Spaniard loves his ancient slop,
The Lumbard his Venetian,
And some, like breech-less women go:
The Russe, Turke, Jew, and Grecian,
The threysly Frenchman wears small waste,
The Dutch his belly boasteth:
The Englishman is for them all;
And for each fashion coasteth.
The Turke in Linen wraps his head,
The Persian his in Lawn too.
The Russe with sables furs his Cap,
And change, will not be drawn too:
The Spaniards constant to his block;
The French, inconstant ever,
But of all Fealts that can be felt,
Give me your English Beaver.
The German loves his Cony-wool:
The Irishman his Shagge-too.
The Welsh his Munmouth loves to wear
And of the same will brag too:
Some love the rough, and some the smooth,
Some great, and others small things,
But O, your lecherous Englishman:
He loves to deal in all things.
The Russe drinks quasses, Dutch, lubecks Beer.
And that is strong, and mighty.
The Brittaine, he Metheglen quaffs,
The Irish, Aqua vitae,
The French affects the Orleance Grape.
The Spaniard tastes his Sherry,
The English none of these can scape:
But he with all makes merry.
The Italian in her high Chapeene,
Scotch Lass, and lovely Froa-too.
The Spanish Donna, French Madam:
He will not fear to go too;
Nothing so full of Hazard dread.
Naught lives above the Centre,
No Fashion, Health, no Wine, nor Wench,
On which he dare not centre.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p:
Good Valerius, this has brought us even to the skirts
of the camp, enter Lords,

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: This Ring my Lord hath opt the gates to you,
For though I know you for a Royal Prince
My sovereigns Son, and friend to Collatine
Without that key you had not entered here.
More lights and see a banquet straight provided,
My love to my dear husband shall appear
In the kind welcome that I give his friend.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: Not lovesick, but love-lunatic, love-mad:
I am all fire, impatience, and my blood
Boils in my heart, with loose and sensual thoughts.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: A chair for the Prince, may it please your highness sit?

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: Madam, with you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: It will become the wife of Collatine to wait upon your trencher.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: You shall sit: behind us at the camp we left our state,
We are but your guest, indeed you shall not wait:
Her modesty hath such strong power over me,
And such a reverence hath fate given her, brow,
That it appears a kind of blasphemy,
To have any wanton word harsh in her ears.
I cannot woo, and yet I love above measure,
It is force not suite must purchase this rich treasure.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Your highness cannot taste such homely eats.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: Indeed I cannot feed (but on thy face,
Thou art the banquet that my thoughts embrace)

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Knew you my Lord, what free and zealous welcome
We tender you, your highness would presume
Upon your entertainment: oft, and many times
I have heard my husband speak of Sextus valour,
Extol your worth, praise your perfection,
to dote upon your valour, and your friendship prise next his Lucrece

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: O impious lust, in all things base, respectless and unjust!
Thy virtue, grace, and fame, I must enjoy,
Though in the purchase I all Rome destroy.
Madam if I be welcome as your virtue bids me presume I am,
Carouse to me a health unto your husband.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: A woman's draught my Lord, to Collatine.

sp.speaker: Sext.
sp.l: Nay you must drink off all.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
Your grace must pardon the tender weakness of a
woman's brain.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: It is to Collatine.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Methinks it would ill become the modesty
Of any Roman Lady to carouse,
And drown her vertues in the juice of grapes.
How can I show my love unto my husband
To do his wife such wrong? by too much wine
I might neglect the charge of this great house
Left solely to my keep, else my example
Might in my servants breed encouragement
So to offend, both which were pardonless,
Else to your Grace I might neglect my duty,
And slack obeisance to so great a guest:
All which being accidental unto wine.
O let me not so wrong my Colatine.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: We excuse you, her perfections like a torrent
With violence breaks upon me, and at once
Inverts and swallows all that is good in me.
Preposterous Fates, what mischiefs you involve
Upon a Caitiff Prince, left to the fury
Of all grand mischief? hath the grandam world
Yet smothered such a strange abortive wonder,
That from her vertues should arise my sin?
I am worst than what is most ill deprived all reason
My heart all fiery lust, my soul all treason.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: My Lord, I fear your health, your changing brow
Hath shown so much disturbance, noble Sextus,
Hath not your venturous travel from the Camp,
sp.p:
Nor the moist rawness of this humorous night impaired your
health?

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: Divinest Lucrece no. I cannot eat.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: To rest then, a rank of torches there, attend the Prince.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: Madam I doubt I am a guest this night.
Too trouble some, and I offend your rest.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p:
This Ring speaks for me, that next Collatine you are to
me most welcome, yet my Lord thus much presume, without
this from his hand, Sextus this night could not have entered
here: no, not the king himself:
sp.l: My doors the day time to my friends are free,
But in the night the obdure gates are less kind.
Without this ring they can no entrance find.
Lights for the Prince.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.p:
A kiss and so goodnight, nay for your rings sake deny
not that.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Iove give your highness soft and sweet repose,

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: And thee the like with soft and sweet content,
My vows are fixed, my thoughts on mischief bent.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: It is late, so many stars shine in this room,
By reason of this great and Princely guest,
The world might call our modesty in question
To revel thus, our husband at the Camp,
Haste and to rest; save in the Princes chamber,
Let not a light appear, my hearts all sadness,
Iove unto thy protection I commit
My chastity and honour to thy keep,
My waking soul I give whilst my thoughts sleep.

body.stage: Exit. Enter Clowne and a Servingman.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
Soft, soft not too loud, imagine we were now going
on the ropes with eggs on our heels, he that hath but a creaking
shoe I would he had a creak in his neck, tread not too
hard for disturbing Prince Sextus.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p:
I wonder the Prince would have none of us stay in his
Chamber and help him to bed.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
What an ass art thou to wonder, there may be many
causes: thou knowest the Prince is a Soldier, and Soldiers many
time want shift: who can say whether he have a clean shirt
on or no: for anything that we know he hath used stavesacre,
or hath taken a medicine to kill the itch, what is that to us, we
did our duty to proffer ourselves.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p:
And what should we enter farther into his thoughts?
come shall Us to bed? I am as drowsy as a dormouse, and my
head is as heavy as though I had a night-cap of lead on.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
And my eyes begin to glue themselves together, I
was till supper was done all together for your repast, and now
after supper I am only for your repose: I think for the two
vertues of eating and sleeping, there never a Roman spirit
under the Cope of heaven can put me down.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p:
For shame what a conjuring, and cater-walling
keep you here, that my Lady cannot sleep: you shall have
her call by and by, and send you all to bed with a witness.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Sweet Mistress Mirable we are going.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p:
You are too loud, come, every man dispose him to
his rest, and I will to mine.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Out with your Torches.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: Come then, and everyman sneak into his kennel.

body.stage: Exeunt. Enter Sextus with his Sword drawne and a Taper light.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: Night be as secret as thou art close, as close
As thou art black and dark thou ominous Queen
Of Tenebrous silence, make this fatal hour
As true to Rape, as thou hast made it kind
To murder, and harsh mischief: Cinthia mask thy cheek,
And all you sparkling element all fires
Choake up your beauties in prodigious sogs,
Or be extinct in some thick vaporous clouds,
Least you behold my practise: I am bound
Upon a black adventure, on a deed
That must wound virtue, and make beauty bleed,
Pause Sextus, and before thou runnest thyself
Into this violent danger, weigh thy sin,
Thou art yet free, beloved, graced in the Camp,
Of great opinion and undoubted hope,
Rome's darling in the universal grace,
Both of the field, and senate: were these fortunes
To make thee great in both, back yet, thy same
Is free from hazard, and thy style from shame,
O fate! thou hast usurped such power over man,
That where thou pleadest thy will no mortal can.
On then black mischief hurry me the way,
Myself I must destroy, her life betray,
The state of King and Subject, the displeasure
Of Prince and people, the revenge of noble,
And the contempt of base the incurred vengeance
Of my wronged kinsman Collatine, the Treason
Against divinest Lucrece: all these total curses
Foreseen not feared upon one Sextus meet,
To make my days harsh: so this night be sweet,
No jar of Clock, no ominous shatefull howl
Of any starting Hound, no horse-cough breathed from the entrails
Of any drowsy Groom, wakes this charmed silence
And starts this general slumber, forward still,
To make thy lust live, all thy vertues kill.
Here, here, behold! beneath these curtains lies
That bright enchantress that hath dazed my eyes.
O who but Sextus could commit such waste?
On one so fair, so kind, so truly chaste?
Or like a ravisher thus rudely stand,
To offend this face, this brow, this lip, this hand?
Or at such fatal hours these revels keep,
With thought once to defile thy innocent sleep,
Save in this breast, such thoughts could find no place,
Or pay with treason her kind hospital grace;
But I am lust-burnt all, bent on what is bad,
That which should calm good thought, makes Tarquin mad.
Madam Lucrece?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Who is that? O me! beshrew you.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: Sweet, it is I.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: What I?

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: Make room.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: My husband Collatine?

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: Thy husband is at the Camp.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Here is no place for any man save him.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: Grant me that grace.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: What are you?

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: Tarquin and thy friend, and must enjoy thee.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Heaven such sins defend.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: Why do you tremble Lady? cease this fear,
I am alone, there is no suspicious ear
That can betray this deed: nay start not sweet.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Dream I, or am I full awake? O no!
I know I dream to see Prince Sextus so.
Sweet Lord awake me, rid me from this terror,
I know you for a Prince, a Gentleman,
Royal and honest, one that loves my Lord,
And would not wrack a woman chastity
For Rome's imperial Diadem, O then
Pardon this dream, for being awake I know
Prince Sextus, Rome's great hope, would not for shame
Havoc his own worth, or despoil my fame.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: I am bent on both, my thoughts are all on fire,
Choose thee, thou must embrace death, or desire.
Yet do I love thee, wilt thou accept it?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: I not thy love, thou must enjoy thy foe.
Where fair means cannot, force shall make my way:
By love I must enjoy thee.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Sweet Lord stay.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: I am all impatience, violence and rage.
And save thy bed naught can this fine assuage: wilt love me?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: No, I cannot.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: Tell me why?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Hate me, and in that hate first let me die.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: By Iove I will force thee.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: By a God you swear, to do a devils deed, sweet Lord forbear
By the same Iove I swear that made this soul,
Never to yield unto an act so foul.
Help, help.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: These pillows first shall stop thy breath,
If thou but shriekest hark how I will frame thy death.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: For death: I care not, so I keep unstained
The uncrazed honour I have yet maintained.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: Thou canst keep neither, for if thou but squeakest
Or letst the least harsh noise jar in my ear,
I will broach thee on my steel, that done, straight murder
One of thy basest Grooms, and lay you both
Grasped arm in arm, on thy adulterate bed,
Then call in witness of that mechall sin,
So shalt thou die, thy death be scandalous,
Thy name be odious, thy suspected body
Denied all funeral rites, and loving Collatine
Shall hate thee even in death: then save all this,
And to thy fortunes add another friend,
Give thy fears comfort, and these torments end.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I will die first, and yet hear me, as ye are noble,
If all your goodness and best generous thoughts
Be not exiled your heart, pity, O pity
The Vertues of a woman: mar not that
Cannot be made again: this once defiled,
Not all the Ocean waves can purify
Or wash my stain away: you seek to soil,
That which the radiant splendour of the Sun
Cannot make bright again: behold my tears,
O think them pearled drops, distilled from the heart
Of Soul-chaste Lucrece: think them Orators,
To plead the cause of absent Collatine, your friend and kinsman.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: Tush, I am obdure.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Then make my name foul, keep my body pure,
O Prince of Princes, do but weigh your sin,
Think how much I shall lose, how small you win.
I lose the the honour of my name and blood,
Loss, Rome's imperial Crown cannot make good.
You win the worlds shame and all good men's hate,
O who would pleasure, buy at such dear rate,
Nor can you term it pleasure, for what is sweet,
Where force and hate, jar and contention meet?
Weigh but for what it is that you urge me still,
To gain a woman's love against her will?
You will but repent such wrong done a chaste wife,
And think that labour is not worth all your strife.
Curse your hot lust, and say you have wronged your friends,
But all the world cannot make me amends,
I took you for a friend, wrong not my trust,
But let these chaste terms quench your fiery lust,

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: No, those moist tears contending with my fire,
Quench not my heat, but make it clime much higher:
I will drag thee hence,

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.p:
If thou raise these cries, lodged in thy slaughtered
arms some base Groom dies.
sp.l: And Rome that hath admired thy name so long
Shall blot thy death with scandal from my tongue.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Iove guard my innocence.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: Lucrece thou art mine:
In spite of Iove and all the powers divine.

body.stage: He beares her out. Enter a Servingman.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p:
What is a Clock trow? my Lord bad me be early
ready with my Gelding, for he would ride betimes in the
morning: now had I rather be up an hour before my time
than a minute after, for my Lord will be so infinite angry if
I but over-sleep myself a moment, that I had better be out
of my life than in his displeasure: but soft, some of my Lord
Collatines men lie in the next chamber, I care not if I call them
Up, for it grows towards day: what Pompey, Pompey?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Who is that calls?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: It is I.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
Who is that, my Lord Sextus his man, what a pox
make you up before day?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p:
I would have the key of the Gate to come at my
Lords Horse in the stable.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
I would my Lord Sextus and you were both in the
hay-loft for Pompey can take none of his natural rest among
you; here is even Ostler rise and give my horse another peck of
hay.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Nay good Pompey help me to the key of the Stable.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
Well, Pompey was born to do Rome good in being
So kind to the young Princes Gelding, but if for my kindness
in giving him Peas and Oats he should kick me, I
should scarce say God a mercy horse: but come, I will go with
thee to the stable.

body.stage: Exeunt Enter Sextus and Lucrece unready.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: Nay, weep not sweet, what is done is past recall,
Call not thy name in question, by this sorrow
Which is yet without blemish, what hath past
Is hid from the worlds eye, and only private
Twixt us, fair Lucrece: pull not on my head,
The wrath of Rome; if I have done thee wrong,
Love was the cause, thy same is without blot.
And thou in Sextus hast a true friend got,
Nay sweet look up, thou only hast my heart,
I must be gone, Lucrece a kiss and part.

body.stage: she flings from him and Exit.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: No? peevish dame farewell, then be the bruiter
Of thy own shame, which Tarquin would conceal,
I am armed against all can come, let mischief frown,
With all his terror armed with ominous fate,
To all their spleens a welcome I will afford,
With this bold heart, strong hand and my good sword.

body.stage: Exit. Enter Brutus, Valerius, Horatius, Aruns, Scevola, Collatine.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.p:
What so early Valerius and your voice not up yet?
thou wast wont to be my Lark, and raise me with thy early
notes.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
I was never so hard set yet my Lord, but I had ever a
fit of mirth for my friend.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.p:
Prithee let us hear it then while we may, for I divine
thy music and my madness are both shore lived, we shall
have somewhat else to do ere long we hope Valerius.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Iove send it.
sp.l: Pack clouds away, and welcome day,
With night we banish sorrow,
Sweet Air blow soft, mount Lark aloft,
To give my love good morrow.
Wings from the wind, to please her mind,
Notes from the Lark I will borrow;
Bird prune thy wing, Nightingale sing:
To give my love good morrow,
To give my love good morrow,
Notes from them all I will borrow.
Wake from thy nest Robin red-breast,
Sing Birds in every Furrow,
And from each bill, let Music shrill,
Give my fair love good morrow,
Blackbird and Thrush, in every Bush,
Stare, Linnet, and Cock-sparrow,
You pretty elves, amongst yourselves,
Sing my fair love good morrow.
To give my love good morrow,
Sing Birds in every Furrow.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.p:
methinks our wars go not well forwards, Horatius
We have greater enemies to bustle with than the Ardeans, if
We durst but front them.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Would it were come to fronting.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.p:
Then we married men should have the advantage of
the bachelors Horatius, especially such as have revelling wives,
those that can caper in the City, while their husbands are
in the Camp, Collatine why are you so sad? the thought of this
should not trouble you, having a Lucrece to your bedfellow.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p:
My Lord I know no cause of discontent, yet cannot
I be merry

sp.speaker: Sce.
sp.p:
Come, come, make him merry, let us have a song in praise
of his Lucrece.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Content.

body.stage: The fourth new Song: In the praise of Lucrece.

sp.l: On two white Columns arched she stands,
Some snow would think them sure;
Some Crystal, others Lilies stripped,
But none of those so pure.
This beauty when I contemplate
What riches I behold,
It is roofed within with virtuous thoughts,
Without, it is thatched with gold.
Two doors then are to enter at,
The one I will not enquire,
Because concealed, the other see we,
Whose sight inflames desire.
Whether the porch be Coral clear,
Or with rich Crimson lined,
Or Rose-leaves, lasting all the year
It is not yet divined.
Her eyes not made of purest glass,
Or Crystal, but transpareth;
The life of Diamonds they surpass,
Their very sight ensnareth.
That which without we rough-cast call,
To stand against wind and weather,
For its rare beauty equals all
That I have named together.
For were it not by modest Art
Kept from the sight of skies,
It would strike dim the Sun itself,
And daze the gazers eyes.
The Case so rich, how may we praise
The jewel lodged within,
To draw their praise I were unwise,
To wrong them it were sin.

sp.speaker: Aru.
sp.p:
I should be frolic if my brother were but returned to
the Camp.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: And in good time behold Prince Sextus.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Health to our General.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.p: Thank you.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.p:
Will you survey your forces, and give order for a present
assault, your soldiers long to be tugging with the
Ardeans.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Have you seen Lucretia my Lord, how fares she?

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.p: Well, I will to my Tent.

sp.speaker: Aru.
sp.p: Why how now, what is the matter brother?

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.p:
Thank you, No, well, I will to my Tent: Get thee to thy
Tent and coward go with thee, if thou hast no more spirit,
to a speedy encounter.

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.p: Shall I go after him and know the cause of his discontent?

sp.speaker: Sce.
sp.p: Or I my Lord?

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.p:
Neither, to pursue a fool in his humour? is the next
way to make him more humorous, I will not be guilty of his
folly, thank you, no, before I wish him health again when
he is sick of the sullens, may I die, not like a Roman, but
like a runagate.

sp.speaker: Sce.
sp.p: Perhaps he is not well.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.p: Well: then let him be.

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.p:
Nay if he be dying I could wish he were, I will ring
out his funeral peal, and this it is.

sp.l: Come list and hark
The Bell doth toll,
For some but new,
Departing soul.
And was not that
Some ominous fowl,
The Bats the Night-Crow
or screech-owle.
To these I hear
The wild-Wolf Howl
In this black night
That seems to Scowl.
All these my black-book,
shall enrol.
For Hark, still still
The Bell doth toll
For some but now
Departing soul.

sp.speaker: Sce.
sp.p: Excellent Valerius, but is not that Collatines man?

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.p: The news with this hasty post.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Did no body see my Lord Collatine? O! my Lady
commends her to you, here is a letter.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Give it me.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Fie upon it, never was poor Pompey so over-laboured
as I have been, I think I have spurred my horse such a question,
that he is scarce able to wig or wag his said for an answer,
but my Lady bad me spare for no horse flesh, and I think I
have made him run his race.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.p: Cousin Collatine the news at Rome?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p:
Nothing but what you all may well partake, read here
my Lord,

sp.l: Dear Lord, if ever thou will see thy Lucrece.
Choose of the friends which thou affectest best,
And all important business set apart,
Repair to Rome: commend me to Lord Brutus,
Valerius, Mutius, Horatius.
Say I in treat their presence, where my Father
Lucretius shall attend them, farewell sweet,
The affairs are great, then do not fail to meet.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: I will thither as I live.

sp.speaker: Col
sp.l: I though I die.

sp.speaker: Sce.
sp.l: To Rome with expeditious wings we will fly.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: The news, the news, if it have any shape
Of sadness, if some prodigy have have chanced,
That may beget revenge, I will cease to chafe,
Vex, martyr, grieve, torture, torment myself,
And tune my humour to strange strains of mirth,
My soul divines some happiness, speak, speak:
I know thou hast some news that will create me
Merry and musical, for I would laugh,
Be new trans-shaped, I prithee sing Valerius that I may air with thee.

sp.speaker: Valerius.
sp.l: I would think myself as proud in Shackles,
As doth the ship in all her Tackles.
The wise-man boasts no more his Brains.
Then I would insult in Gyves and Chains:
As Creditors would use there Debters,
So could I toss and shake my Fetters,
But not confess, my thoughts should be
In durance fast as those kept me.
And could when spite their hurts Environs.
Then dance to the music of my Irons.

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.p: Now tell us what is the project of thy message?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
My Lords, the Princely Sextus has been at home, but
what he hath done there I may partly mistrust, but cannot
altogether resolve you: besides, my Lady swore me, that
whatsoever I suspected I should say nothing.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
If thou wilt not say thy mind I prithee sing thy
mind, and then thou mayst save thine oath.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Indeed I was not sworn to that, I may either laugh
out my news or sing them, and so I may save mine oath to my
Lady.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: How is all at Rome, that with such sad presage
Disturbed Collatine and noble Brutus
Are hurried from the Camp with Scevola?
And we with expedition amongst the rest,
Are charged to Rome? speak what did Sextus there with thy fair Mistress?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Second me my Lord, and we will urge him to disclose it.

body.stage: Valerius, Horatius, and the Clowne their Catch.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Did he take fair Lucrece by the toe man?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Toe man.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Aye man.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: Ha ha ha ha ha man.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: And further did he strive to go man?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: Go man.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Aye man.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: Ha ha ha ha man, fa derry derry downe ha fa derry dino.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Did he take fair Lucrece by the heele man?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: Heele man.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Aye man.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: Ha ha ha ha man.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: And did he further strive to feele man?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: Feele man.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Aye man.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Ha ha ha ha man, ha fa derry. etcetera.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Did he take the Lady by the shin man?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: Shin man.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Aye man.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: Ha ha ha ha man.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Further too would he have been man?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: Been man.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Aye man.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: Ha ha ha ha man, Ha fa derry, etcetera.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Did he take the lady by the knee man?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: Knee man.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Aye man.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: Ha ha ha ha man.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Farther than that would he be man?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: Be man.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Aye man.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: Ha ha ha ha man, hey fa derry, etcetera.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Did he take the Lady by the thigh man.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: Thigh man.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Aye man.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: Ha ha ha ha man

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: And now he came it somewhat nigh man.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: Nigh man.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Aye man.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: Ha ha ha ha man, Hey fa derry, etcetera.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: But did he do the tother thing man?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: Thing man?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Aye man.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: Ha ha ha ha man.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: And at the same had he a fling man.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Fling man.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Aye man.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Hay ha ha man, hey fa derry, etcetera.

body.stage: Exeunt. A Table and a Chaire covered with blacke. Lucrece and her Maid.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Mirable.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: Madam.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Is not my father old Lucretius come yet?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: Not yet.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Nor any from the Camp?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: Neither Madam.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Go, begone, and leave me to the truest grief of heart,
That ever entered any Matrons breast: O!

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: Why weep you Lady? alas why do you stain
Your modest cheeks with these offensive tears?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Nothing, nay, nothing: O you powerful Gods,
That should have Angels guardians on your throne.
To protect innocence and chastity! O why
Suffer you such inhumane massacre
On harmless virtue? wherefore take you charge,
On sinless souls to see them wounded thus
With Rape or violence? or give white innocence,
Armour of proof against sin: or by oppression
Kill virtue quite, and guerdon base transgression?
Is it my fate above all other women?
Or is my sin more heinous than the rest,
That amongst Thousands, millions, infinities,
I, only I, should to this shame be born,
To be a stain to women, natures scorn? O!

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: What ails you Madam, truth you make me weep
To see you shed salt tears: what hath oppressed you?
Why is your chamber hung with mourning black?
Your habit sable, and your eyes thus swollen
With ominous tears, alas what troubles you?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I am not sad, thou didst deceive thyself,
I did not weep there is nothing troubles me,
But wherefore dost thou blush?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: Madam not I.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Indeed thou didst, and in that blush my gilt thou didst betray
How camest thou by the notice of my sin?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: What sin?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: My blot, my scandal, and my shame:
O Tarquin, thou my honour didst betray,
Disgrace no time, no age can wipe away, O!

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: Sweet Lady cheer yourself, I will fetch my Viol,
And see if I can sing you fast asleep,
A little rest would wear away this passion.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Do what thou wilt, I can command no more,
Being no more a woman, I am now
Devote to death and an inhabitant
Of the other world: these eyes must ever weep
Till fate hath closed them with eternal sleep.

body.stage: Enter Brutus, Collatine, Horatius, Scevola, Valerius one way Lucretius another way.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Brutus!

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Lucretius.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Father!

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Lucrece!

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Collatine!

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: How cheer you Madam? how is it with you cousin?
Why is your eye deject and drowned in sorrow?
Why is this funeral black, and ornaments
Of widowhood? resolve me cousin Lucrece.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: How fare you Lady?

sp.speaker: Old Luc.
sp.l: What is the matter girl?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Why how is it with you Lucrece, tell me sweet?
Why dost thou hide thy face? and with thy hand
Darken those eyes that were my Sons of joy,
To make my pleasures flourish in the Spring?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: O me!

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Whence are these sighs and tears?

sp.speaker: Sce.
sp.l: How grows this passion?

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Speak Lady, you are hemmed in with your friends.
Girt in a pale of safety, and environed
And circled in a fortress of your kindred.
Let not those drops fall fruitless to the ground,
Nor let your sighs add to the senseless wind.
Speak, who hath wronged you?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Ere I speak my woe,
Swear you will revenge poor Lucrece on her foe.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Be his head arched with gold.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Be his hand armed with an imperial Sceptre.

sp.speaker: Old Luc.
sp.l: Be he great as Tarquin, throned in an imperial seat.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Be he no more than mortal, he shall feele
The vengeful edge of this victorious steel.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Then seat you Lords, whilst I express my wrong.
Father dear husband, and my kinsman, Lords,
Hear me, I am dishonoured and disgraced,
My reputation mangled, my renown
disparaged, but my body, O my body.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: What Lucrece?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Stained, polluted, and defiled.
Strange steps are found in my adulterate bed,
And though my thoughts be white as innocence,
Yet is my body soiled with lust-burned sin,
And by a stranger I am strumpeted,
Ravished, enforced, and am no more to rank among the Roman Matrons.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Yet cheer you Lady, and restrain these tears,
If you were forced the sin concerns not you,
A woman is born but with woman's strength: who was the Ravisher?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p:
Aye, name him Lady, our love to you shall only thus
appear in the revenge that we will take on him.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I hope so Lords, it was Sextus the Kings Son.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: How? Sextus Tarquin!

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: That unprincely Prince, who guest-wise entered with my husbands Ring,
This Ring, O Collatine! this Ring you sent
Is cause of all my woe, your discontent.
I feasted him, then lodged him, and bestowed
My choicest welcome, but in the dead of night
My traitorous guest came armed unto my bed,
Frighted my silent sleep, threatened, and prayed
For entertainment: I despised both.
Which hearing, his sharp pointed Scimitar
The Tyrant bent against my naked breast,
Alas, I begged my death, but note his tyranny
He brought with him a torment worse than death,
For having murdered me, he Swore to kill
One of my basest Grooms, and lodge him dead
In my dead arms: then call in testimony
Of my adultery, to make me hated
Even in my death, of husband, father, friends,
Of Rome and all the world: this, this, O princes, Ravished and killed me at once.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Yet comfort Lady, I quit thy guilt, for what could
Lucrece do more than a woman? hadst thou died polluted
By this base scandal, thou hadst wronged thy fame:
And hindered us of a most just revenge.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: What shall we do Lords?

sp.speaker: Bru:
sp.l: Lay your resolute hands upon the sword of Brutus,
Vow and swear, as you hope meed for merit from the Gods,
Or fear reward for sin, from devils below:
As you are Romans, and esteem your fame
More than your lives, all humorous toys set off.
Of madding, singing, smiling, and what else,
Receive your native valours, be yourselves,
And join with Brutus in the just revenge
Of this chaste ravished Lady, swear.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: We do.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Then with your humours here my grief ends too,
My stain I thus wipe off, call in my sighs,
And in the hope of this revenge, forbear
Even to my death to fall one passionate tear,
Yet Lords, that you may crown my innocence
With your best thoughts, that you may henceforth know
We are the same in heart we seem in show.
And though I quit my soul of all such sin,
I will not debar my body punishment:
Let all the world, learn of a Roman dame,
To prise her life less than her honoured fame.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.l: Lucrece.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Wife.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Lady.

sp.speaker: Scov.
sp.l: She hath slain herself.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: O see yet Lords if there be hope of life,

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: She is dead, then turn your funeral tears to fire
And indignation, let us now redeem
Our misspent time, and over take our sloth
With hostile expedition, this great Lords,
This bloody knife, on which her chaste blood flowed,
sp.p:
Shall not from Brutus till some strange revenge fall on the
heads of Tarquins.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Now is the time to call their pride to compt,
Brutus lead on, We will follow thee to their confusion.

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.l: By Iove we will, the sprightful youth of Rome
Tricked up in plumed harness shall attend
sp.p:
The march of Brutus, whom we here create our General
against the Tarquins.

sp.speaker: Sce.
sp.l: Be it so.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: We embrace it: now to stir the wrath of Rome,
You, Collatine and good Lucretius,
With eyes yet drowned in tears, bear that chaste body
Into the market place: that horrid object,
Shall kindle them with a most just revenge.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: To see the father and the husband mourn
Over this chaste Dame, that have so well deserved
Of Rome and them, than to infer the pride,
The wrongs and the perpetual tyranny
Of all the Tarquins, Sercius Tullius death,
And his unnatural usage by that Monster
Tullia the Queen. All these shall well concur in a combined revenge.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Lucrece, thy death we will mourn in glittering arms
And plumed casks: bear that reverend load,
Unto the Forum where our force shall meet
To set upon the pallas, and expel
This viperous brood from Rome: I know the people
Will gladly embrace our fortunes: Scevola,
Go you and muster powers in Brutus name.
Valerius, you assist him instantly,
And to the mazed people freely speak the cause of this concourse.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: We go.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: And you dear Lord, whose speechless grief is boundless.
Turn all your tears with ours, to wrath and rage,
The hearts of all the Tarquins shall weep blood
Upon the funeral Hearse, with whose chaste body,
Honour your arms, and to the assembled people,
Disclose her innocent wounds: Gramercies Lords,
sp.stage: A great shout and a flourish with drums and Trumpets
sp.l: That universal shout tells me their words
Are gracious with the people, and their troops
Are ready embattled, and expect but us
To lead them on, Iove give our fortunes speed.
We will murder, murder, and base rape shall bleed.

body.stage: Alarum, Enter in the fight Tarquin and Tullia flying, pursude by Brutus, and the Romans march with Drum and Colors, Porsenna, Aruns, Sextus, Tarquin, and Tullia meets and joynes with them: To them Brutus and the Romans with Drum and souldiers: they make a stand.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Even thus far Tyrant have we dogged thy steps,
Frighting thy Queen and thee with horrid steel:

sp.speaker: Tar.
sp.l: Lodged in the safety of Porsennaes arms,
Now Traitor Brutus we dare front thy pride:

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Porsenna thou art unworthy of a sceptre,
To shelter pride, lust, rape, and tyranny,
In that proud Prince and his confederate Peers.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: Traitors to heaven: to Tarquin, Rome and us,
Treason to Kings doth stretch even to the Gods,
And those high Gods that take great Rome in charge,
shall punish your rebellion.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: O Devil Sextus, speak not thou of Gods,
Nor cast those false and fained eyes to heaven,
Whose rape the furies must torment in Hell,
of Lucrece, Lucrece.

sp.speaker: Sce.
sp.p:
Her chaste blood still cries for vengeance to the Ethereal
deities.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: O it was a foul deed Sextus.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And thy shame shall be eternal and out live her fame.

sp.speaker: Aru.
sp.l: Say Sextus loved her, was she not a woman,
Aye, and perhaps was willing to be forced,
Must you being private subjects dare to Ring
Wars loud alarum against your potent King?

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Brutus therein thou dost forget thyself,
sp.p:
And wrongest the glory of thine Ancestors, staining thy
blood with Treason.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.p:
Tuscan know the Consul Brutus is their powerful
foe.

sp.speaker: All Tarquine.
sp.l: Consul.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Aye consul and the powerful hand of Rome
Grasps his imperial sword: the name of King
The Tyrant Tarquins have made odious
Unto this nation and the general knee
Of this our warlike people, now low bends
To royal Brutus where the Kings name end.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Now Sextus where is the Oracle, when I kissed
My Mother earth it plainly did foretell,
My Noble vertues did thy sin exceed,
Brutus should sway, and lust burnt Tarquin bleed.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Now shall the blood of Servius, fall as heavy
sp.p:
As a huge mountain on your Tyrant heads, over whelming
all your glory.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Tullia's guilt, shall be by us revenged, that in her pride
In blood paternal, her rough coach-wheels died.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Your Tyrannies:

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Pride.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p:
And my Lucrece fate, shall all be swallowed in this
hostile hate.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: O Romulus, thou that first reared yon walls
In sight of which we stand, in thy soft bosom
Is hugged, the nest in which the Tarquins build;
Within the branches of thy lofty spires
Tarquin shall perch, or where he once hath stood,
His high built airy shall be drowned in blood;
Alarum then Brutus by heaven I vow,
My sword shall prove thou never wast made till now.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Sextus, my madness with your lives expires,
Thy sensual eyes are fixed upon that wall,
Thou never shall enter, Rome confines you all.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: A charge then.

sp.speaker: Tar.
sp.l: Iove and Tarquin.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: But we cry a Brutus.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Lucrece, fame and victory.

body.stage: Alarum, the Romans are beaten off. Alarum, Enter Brutus, Horatius Valerius, Scevola, Lucretius and Collatine.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Thou Jovial hand hold up thy Sceptre high,
And let not Justice be oppressed with Pride,
O you Penates leave not Rome and us,
sp.p:
Grasped in the purple hands of death and ruin, the Tarquins
have the best.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Yet stand, my foot is fixed upon this bridge; Tiber,
Thy arched streams shall be changed crimson, with
The Roman blood before I budge from hence.

sp.speaker: Sce.
sp.l: Brutus retire, for if thou enter Rome
We are all lost, stand not on valour now,
But save thy people, let us survive this day,
To try the fortunes of another field.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
Break down the Bridge least the pursuing enemy
Enter with us and take the spoil of Rome.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p:
Then break behind me, for by heaven I will grow
And root my foot as deep as to the centre, before I leave
this passage.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Come you are mad.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p:
The foe comes on, and we in trifling here, hazard
ourself and people.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p:
Save them all, to make Rome stand, Horatius here will
fall.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: We would not lose thee, do not breast thyself
Against thousands, if thou frontest them, thou art ringed
With million swords and darts, and we behind
Must break the Bridge of Tyber to save Rome.
Before thee infinite gaze on thy face.
sp.p:
And menace death, the raging streams of Tyber are at thy
back to swallow thee.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Retire, to make Rome live, it is death that I desire.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Then farewell dead Horatius, think in us
The universal arm of Potent Rome,
Takes his last leave of thee in this embrace.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Farewell.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Farewell.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.p:
These arches all must down to interdict their passage
through the town.

body.stage: Exeunt. Alarum, Enter Tarquin, Porsenna, and Aruns with their pikes and Targeters.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Enter, enter, enter.

body.stage: A noise of knocking downe the bridge. within.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Soft Tarquin, See a bulwark to the bridge,
You first must pass, the man that enters here
Must make his passage through Horatius breast,
See with this Target do I buckler Rome,
And with this sword defy the puissant army of two great Kings.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: One man to face an host!
Charge soldiers, of full forty thousand Romans
There is but one daring hand against your host,
To keep you from the sack or spoil of Rome, charge, charge.

sp.speaker: Aruns.
sp.l: Upon them Soldiers,

body.stage: Alarum, Alarum. Enter in severall places, Sextus and Valerius above.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: O cowards slaves, and vassals, what not enter?
Was it for this you placed my regiment
Upon a hill to be the sad spectator
Of such a general cowardice? Tarquin, Aruns,
Porsenna, soldiers pass Horatius quickly,
For they behind him will devolve the bridge,
And raging Tyber that is impassable,
Your host must swim before you conquer Rome.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Yet stand Horatius, bear but one brunt more,
The arched bridge shall sink upon his piles.
And in his fall lift thy renown to heaven.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: Yet enter.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
Dear Horatius, yet stand and save a million by one
powerful hand.

body.stage: Alarum, and the falling of the Bridge.

sp.speaker: Aruns and all.
sp.l: Charge, charge, charge.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: Degenerate slaves, the Bridge is fallen Rome is lost.

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.l: Horatius, thou art stronger than their host,
Thy strength is valour, theirs are idle braves,
Now save thyself, and leap into the waves.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Porsenna, Tarquin, now wade past your depths
And enter Rome, I feel my body sink
Beneath my ponderous weight, Rome is preserved,
And now farewell; for he that follows me
Must search the bottom of this raging stream,
Fame with thy golden wings renown my Crest,
And Tyber take me on thy silver breast.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: He has leapt off from the bridge and drowned himself.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: You are deceived, his spirit soars too high
To be choked in with the base element
Of water, lo he swims armed as he was,
Whilst all the army have discharged their arrows,
Of which the shield upon his back sticks full.
And hark, the shout of all the multitude
Now welcomes him a land: Horatius fame
Hath checked our armies with a general shame,
But come, tomorrow's fortune must restore
This scandal, which I of the Gods implore.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Then we must find another time fair Prince
To scourge these people, and revenge your wrongs.
For this night I will betake me to my tent.

body.stage: A Table and Lights in the tent.

sp.speaker: Tar.
sp.l: And we to ours, tomorrow we will renown
Our army with the spoil of this rich Town.

body.stage: Exit Tarquin cum suis. Enter Secretary.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Our Secretary.

sp.speaker: Secret.
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Command Lights and Torches in our Tents.
And let a guard engirt our safety round,
Whilst we debate of Military business:
Come, sit and let us consult.

sp.speaker: Scev.
sp.l: Horatius, famous for defending Rome,
But we have done naught worthy Scevola,
Nor a Roman: I in this disguise
Have past the army and the pursuant guard
Of King Porsenna: this should be his tent;
And in good time, now fate direct my strength
Against a King, to free great Rome at length.

sp.speaker: Secret.
sp.l: O I am slain, treason, treason.

sp.speaker: Porsen.
sp.l: Villain what hast thou done?

sp.speaker: Scevo.
sp.l: Why slain the King.

sp.speaker: Porsen.
sp.l: What King?

sp.speaker: Scevo.
sp.l: Porsenna.

sp.speaker: Porsen.
sp.l: Porsenna lives to see thee tortured,
With plagues more devilish than the pains of Hell.

sp.speaker: Sce.
sp.l: O too rash Mutius, hast thou missed thy aim?
And thou base hand that didst direct my Poniard
Against a Peasant's breast, behold thy error
Thus I will punish: I will give thee freely
Unto the fire, nor will I wear a limb,
That with such rashness shall offend his Lord.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: What will the madman do?

sp.speaker: Sce.
sp.l: Porsenna so, punish my hand thus, for not killing thee.
Three hundred noble lads beside myself
Have vowed to all the gods that patron Rome,
Thy ruin for supporting tyranny:
And though I fail, expect yet every hour,
When some strange fate thy fortunes will devour.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Stay Roman, we admire thy constancy,
And scorn of fortune, go, return to Rome,
We give thee life, and say, The king Porsenna,
Whose life thou seekst is in this honourable,
Pass freely, guard him to the walls of Rome,
And were we not so much engaged to Tarquin,
sp.p:
We would not lift a hand against that nation that breeds
such noble spirits.

sp.speaker: Scev.
sp.l: Well. I go, and for revenge take life even of my foe.

sp.speaker: Pors.
sp.l: Conduct him safely: what three hundred Gallants
Sworn to our death, and all resolved like him!
We will prove for Tarquin, if they fail our hopes,
Peace shall be made with Rome, but first our secretary
Shall have his rights of Funeral, then our shield
We must address next for tomorrow's field.

body.stage: Exit. Enter Brutus, Horatius, Valerius, Collatine, Lucrece Marching.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: By thee we are Consul, and still govern Rome,
Which but for thee, had been despoiled and taken,
Made a confused heap of men and stones,
Swimming in blood and slaughter, dear Horatius
Thy noble picture shall be carved in brass,
And fixed for thy perpetual memory in our high Capital.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Great Consul Thanks, but leaving this, let us
March out of the City.
And once more bid them battle on the plains.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: This day my soul divines we shall live free
sp.p:
From all the furious Tarquins: but where is Scevola? We see
not him today?

sp.l: Here Lords, behold me handless as you see.
The cause I missed Porsenna in his tent,
And in his stead killed but his secretary.
The moved King when he beheld me punish
My rash mistake, with loss of my right hand,
Unbegged and almost scorned he gave me life.
Which I had then refused, but in desire to venge fair Lucrece
Rape.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Dear Scevola thou hast exceeded us in our resolve,
But will the Tarquins give us present battle?

sp.speaker: Sce.
sp.p:
That may ye hear, the Skirmish is begun already
twixt the horse.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Then noble Consul lead our main Battle on.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.p:
O Iove this day balance our cause, and let her innocent
blood, destroy the heads of all the Tarquins, see this day
sp.l: In her cause do we consecrate our lives.
And in defence of Justice now march on:
I hear their Martial music, be our shock
As terrible as are the meeting clouds
That break in thunder, yet our hopes are fair,
And this rough charge shall all our hopes repair.

body.stage: Exeunt, Alarum battell within. Enter Porsenna and Aruns.

sp.speaker: Porsen.
sp.p:
Yet grow our lofty plumes unflagged with blood,
And yet sweet pleasure wantons in the air: How goes the
battle Aruns?

sp.speaker: Aru.
sp.p:
It is even balanced, I enter changed with Brutus hand to
hand a dangerous encounter, both are wounded, and had not
the rude press divided us, one had dropped down to earth.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.p:
It was bravely fought. I saw the King your father free
his person from Thousand Romans that begirt his state, where
flying arrows thick as atoms sung about his ears.

sp.speaker: Aru.
sp.p:
I hope a glorious day, come Tuscan King let us on
them.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p:
Aruns stay, that sword that late did drink the Consuls
blood, must with keen fang tire upon my flesh, or this on
thine.

sp.speaker: Aruns.
sp.p:
It spared the Consuls life to end thy days in a
more glorious strife.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I stand against thee Tuscan,

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: I for thee.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Where ere I find a Tarquin he is for me.

body.stage: Alarum, fight, Aruns slain, Porsenna Expulst, Alarum, Enter Tarquin with an arrow in his brest, Tullia with him, pursude by Collatine, Lucretius, Scevola.

sp.speaker: Tar.
sp.l: Fair Tullia leave me, save thyself by flight,
Since mine is desperate, behold I am wounded
Even to the death: there stays within my tent
A winged Jennet, mount his back and fly,
Live to revenge my death since I must die.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.l: Had I the heart to tread upon the bulk
Of my dead father, and to see him slaughtered,
Only for the love of Tarquin and a Crown,
And shall I fear death more than loss of both?
No, this is Tullia's fame, rather than fly
From Tarquin, amongst a thousand swords she will die.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Hew them to pieces both.

sp.speaker: Tar.
sp.l: My Tullia save,
And over my caitiff head those Meteors wave.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.l: Let Tullia yield then.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.l: Yield me, Cuckold no;
Mercy I scorn, let me the danger know.

sp.speaker: Sce.
sp.l: Upon them then.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Let us bring them to their fate,
And let them perish in the peoples hate.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.l: Fear not, I will back thee husband.

sp.speaker: Tar.
sp.l: But for thee,
Sweet were the hand that this charged soul could free,
Life I despise, let noble Sextus stand
To avenge our death, even till these vitals end,
Scorning my own, thy life will I defend.

sp.speaker: Tul.
sp.l: And I will sweet Tarquin to my power guard thine,
Come on ye slaves and make this earth divine.

body.stage: Alarum, Tarquin and Tullia slaine. Alarum, Brutus all bloody.

sp.speaker: Brut.
sp.l: Aruns, this crimson favour for thy sake,
I will wear upon my forehead masked with blood,
Till all the moisture in the Tarquins veins
Be spilt upon the earth, and leave thy body
As dry as the parched Summer, burnt and scorched with the Canicular stars.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Aruns lies dead,
By this bright sword that towered about his head.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p:
And see great Consul, where the pride of Rome lies
sunk and fallen.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
Besides him lies the Queen mangled and hewn amongst
the Roman Soldiers.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p:
Lift up their slaughtered bodies, help to rear them against
this hill in view of all the Camp.
This fight will be a terror to the foe, and make them
yield or fly.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.p:
But where is the Ravisher, injurious Sextus, that we see
not him?

sp.speaker: Sex
sp.l: Through broken spears, cracked swords, unboweled steeds,
Flawed armours, mangled limbs, and battered casks,
sp.p:
Knee deep in blood, I have pierced the Roman host to be my
Fathers rescue.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p:
It is too late, his mounting pride is sunk in the peoples
hate.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: My Father, Mother, Brother! fortune, now
I do defy thee, I expose myself
To horrid danger, safety I despise:
I dare the worst of peril, I am bound.
On till this pile of flesh be all one wound.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Begirt him Lords, this is the Ravisher,
There is no revenge for Lucrece till he fall.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Cease Sextus then:

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.p:
Sextus defies you all; yet will you give me language
ere I die.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Say on.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: It is not for mercy, for I scorn that life
That is given by any, and the more to add
To your immense unmeasurable hate,
I was the spur unto my fathers pride,
It was I that awed the Princes of the land;
That made thee Brutus mad, these discontent:
I ravished the chaste Lucrece; Sextus I,
Thy daughter, and thy wife, Brutus thy Cousin,
Allied indeed to all; it was for my Rape,
sp.p:
Her constant hand ripped up her innocent breast, it was Sextus did
all this.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Which I will revenge.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Leave that to me.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Old as I am I will doo'r.

sp.speaker: Sce.
sp.p:
I have one hand left yet, of strength enough to kill
a Ravisher.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: Come all at once, Aye all; yet hear me Brutus,
Thou art honourable,
And my words tend to thee: My father died
By many hands, What is he amongst you can challenge
The least, Aye smallest honour in his death?
If I be killed among this hostile throng,
The poorest snaky soldier well may claim
As much renown in noble Sextus death,
As Brutus, thou, or thou Horatius:
I am to die, and more than die I cannot.
Rob not yourselves of honour in my death.
When the two mightiest spirits of Greece and Troy,
Tugged for the mastery, Hector and Achillis,
Had puissant Hector by Achillis hand,
Died in single monomachy, Achillis
Had been the Worthy: but being slain by odds,
The poorest Myrmidon had as much honour
As faint Achillis in the Trojans death.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Hadst thou not done a deed so execrable
That gods and men abhor, I would love thee Sextus,
And hug thee for this challenge breathed so freely:
Behold, I stand for Rome as General,
Thou of the Tarquins dost alone survive,
The head of all these garboils, the chief actor
Of that black sin, which we chastise by arms.
Brave Romans, with your bright swords be our lists,
And ring us in, none dare to offend the Prince
By the least touch, lest he incur our wrath:
This honour do your Consul, that his hand
May punish this arch-mischief, that the times
Succeeding may of Brutus thus much tell,
By him, Pride, Lust, and all the Tarquins fell.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: To ravish Lucrece Cuckold Collatine,
And spill the chastest blood that ever ran
In any Matrons veins, repents me not
So much as to have wronged a Gentleman
So noble as the Consul in this strife.
Brutus be bold, thou sights with one scorns life.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: And thou with one, that less than his renown,
Priseth his blood, or Rome's imperial Crown.

body.stage: Alarum, a fierce fight with sword and target; then after pause and breathe.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Sextus stand fair, much honour shall I win
To revenge Lucrece, and chastise thy sin.

sp.speaker: Sext.
sp.l: I repent nothing, may I live or die,
Though my blood fall, my spirit shall mount on hie.

body.stage: Alarum, fight with single swords, and being deadly wounded and panting for breath, making a stroak at each together with their gantlets they fall.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Both slain! O noble Brutus, this thy fame
To after ages shall survive; thy body
shall have a fair and gorgeous Sepulchre:
For whom the Matrons shall in funeral black
Mourn twelve sad Moons, thou that first governed Rome,
And swayed the people by a Consuls name.
These bodies of the Tarquins we will commit
Unto the funeral pile: you Collatine
Shall succeed Brutus, in the Consuls place,
Whom with this Laurel wreath we here create.
Such is the peoples voice, accept it then.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: We do, and may our power so just appear,
Rome may have peace, both with our love and fear.
But soft, what march is this?

body.stage: Florish. Porsenna, Drum, Collatine and Souldiers.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: The Tuscan King, seeing the Tarquins slain,
Thus armed and battled offers peace to Rome:
To confirm which, we will give you present hostage;
If you deny, we will stand upon our guard,
And by the force of arms, maintain our own.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: After so much effusion and large waste
Of Roman blood, the name of peace is welcome:
Since of the Tarquins none remain in Rome,
And Lucrece Rape is now revenged at fall,
It were good to entertain Porsenna's League.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Porsenna we embrace, whose Royal presence
Shall grace the Consul to the funeral pile.
March on to Rome, love be our guard and guide,
That hath in us, venged Rape, and punished Pride.

div1.head: To the Reader. Because we would not that any mans expectation should be deceived in the ample Printing of this Book: Lo, (Gentle Reader) we have inserted these few Songs, which were added by the stranger that lately acted Valerius his part, in forme following.

sp.l: Thus go the cries in Rome fair town,
First they go up street, and then they go down.
Roved and sound all of a coller,
Buy a very fine marking stone, marking stone,
Round and sound all of a coller,
Buy a very fine marking stone a very very fine.
Thus go the cries in Rome fair town,
First they go up street, and then they go down
Bread and -- meat -- bread -- and meat
For the -- ten--der -- mercy of God to the
poor pris--ners of Newgate, four-score
and ten -- poor -- prisoners.
Thus go the cries in Rome fair town,
First they go up street, and then they go down.
Salt -- salt -- white Wor--stershire salt,
Thus go the cries in Rome fair town,
First they go up street, and then they go down.
Buy a very fine Mouse trap, or a tormentor
for your Fleas.
Thus go the cries in Rome fair town,
First they go up street, and then they go down.
Kitchen stuff maids,
Thus go the cries in Rome fair town,
First they go up street, and then they go down.
Have you any Wood to cleave?
Thus go the cries in Rome fair town,
First they go up street, and then they go down.
I have white Radish, white
hard Lettuce, white young Onions.
Thus go the cries in Rome fair town,
First they go up street, and then they go down.
I have Rock-Sampier, Rock-Sampier.
Thus go the cries in Rome fair town,
First they go up street, and then they go down.
Buy a Mat, a Mil mat,
Mat, a Hassock for your pew,
A stopple for a close stool,
Or a Pea-sock to thrust your feet in.
Thus go the cries in Rome fair town,
First they go up street, and then they go down.
Whiting maids Whiting.
Thus go the cries in Rome fair town,
First they go up street, and then they go down.
Hot fine Oat-cakes, hot.
Thus go the cries in Rome fair town,
First they go up street, and then they go down.
small-coals here.
Thus go the cries in Rome fair town,
First they go up street, and then they go down.
Will you buy any Milk today.
Thus go the cries in Rome fair town,
First they go up street, and then they go down.
Lantern and Candle light here
Maid, a light here.
Thus go the cries in Rome fair town,
First they go up street, and then they go down.
Here lies a company of very poor
Women, in the dark dungeon,
Hungry cold and comfortless night and day,
Pity the poor women in the dark dungeon.
Thus go the cries where they do house them,
First they come to the grate, and then
They go louse them.

lg.l: Arise, arise, my Iuggie my Puggie,
arise get up my dear,
The weather is cold, it blows, it snows,
O let me be lodged here.
My Iuggie my Puggie, my honey my cony,
my love, my dove, my dear,
O O, the weather is cold, it blows, it snows,
O O, let me lodged here.
Begone, begone, my Willie, my Billie,
begone, begone my dear,
The weather is warm, it will do thee no harm,
thou canst not be lodged here.
My Willy, my Billie, my honey my cony,
my love, my dove, my dear,
O O, the weather is warm, it will do thee no harm
O O, thou canst not be lodged here.
Farewell, farewell, my Iuggie, my Puggie,
farewell, farewell my dear,
Then will I begone from whence that I came,
if I cannot be lodged here.
My Iuggie my Puggie, my honey, my cony,
my love, my dove, my dear,
O O, then will I be gone, from whence that I came,
O O, o, if I cannot be lodged here.
Return, return my Willy, my Billy,
return my dove and my dear,
The weather doth change, then seem not strange,
thou shalt be lodged here.
My Willie, my Bille, my honey, my cony.
my love, my dove, my dear,
